297. At the same meeting, the representative of Japan made a statement in explanation of vote before the vote.

298. Also at the same meeting, at the request of the representative of Pakistan, a recorded vote was taken on the draft resolution. The draft resolution was adopted by 26 votes to 2, with 17 abstentions.

299. For the text as adopted and voting results, see part one, chapter I, resolution 22/23.

Situation of human rights in the Syrian Arab Republic

300. At the 49th meeting, on 22 March 2013, the representative of Morocco introduced draft resolution A/HRC/22/L.31/Rev.1, sponsored by Jordan, Kuwait, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia and the United Arab Emirates and co-sponsored by Australia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Canada, Cape Verde, Georgia, Iceland, Maldives, Turkey and the United States of America. Subsequently, Andorra, Austria, Bahrain, Belgium, Benin, Botswana, Bulgaria, Chile, Costa Rica, Cte dIvoire, Croatia, Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Djibouti, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Honduras, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Latvia, Libya, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Mexico, Montenegro, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Nigeria, Norway, Oman, Poland, Portugal, the Republic of Korea, the Republic of Moldova, Romania, San Marino, Senegal, Slovakia, Slovenia, South Sudan, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and Yemen joined the sponsors.

301. At the same meeting, the representative of Morocco orally revised the draft resolution.

302. Also at the same meeting, the representatives of Brazil, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Ireland (on behalf of States members of the European Union that are members of the Council), Switzerland, the United States of America and Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of) made general comments in relation to the draft resolution.

303. At the same meeting, the representative of the Syrian Arab Republic made a statement as the country concerned.

304. In accordance with rule 153 of the rules of procedure of the General Assembly, the attention of the Council was drawn to the estimated administrative and programme budget implications of the draft resolution. The Chief of OHCHR Programme Support and Management Services made a statement in relation to the budgetary implications of the draft resolution as orally revised.

305. At the same meeting, the representatives of Indonesia and Pakistan made statements in explanation of vote before the vote.

306. Also at the same meeting, at the request of the representative of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, a recorded vote was taken on the draft resolution as orally revised. The draft resolution, as orally revised, was adopted by 41 votes to 1, with 5 abstentions.

307. For the text as adopted and voting results, see part one, chapter I, resolution 22/24.

308. At the same meeting, the representative of Argentina made a statement in explanation of vote after the vote.

 

V. Human rights bodies and mechanisms

A. Forum on Minority Issues

309. At the 31st meeting, on 12 March 2013, the Independent Expert on minority issues, Rita Izsk, introduced the recommendations adopted by the Forum on Minority Issues at its fifth session, held on 27 and 28 November 2012 (A/HRC/22/60).

B. Advisory Committee

310. At the 31st meeting, on 12 March 2013, the President of the Human Rights Council stated that the Council had before it four studies submitted by the Advisory Committee pursuant to Council mandates (A/HRC/22/61, A/HRC/22/70, A/HRC/22/71 and A/HRC/22/72).

C. Complaint procedure

311. At the 46th meeting, on 20 March 2013, the Human Rights Council held a closed meeting of the complaint procedure.

312. At the 47th meeting, on 21 March 2013, the President made a statement on the outcome of the meetings, stating that the Human Rights Council had examined, in a closed meeting, the report of the Working Group on Situations on its eleventh session, under the complaint procedure established pursuant to Human Rights Council resolution 5/1. No case was referred by the Working Group on Situations to the Human Rights Council for action at its twenty-second session.

D. General debate on agenda item 5

313. At its 31st meeting, on 12 March 2013, and at the 32nd meeting, on 13 March 2013, the Human Rights Council held a general debate on agenda item 5, during which the following made statements:

(a) Representatives of States Members of the Human Rights Council: Austria, Gabon (on behalf of the Group of African States), Hungary[53] (also on behalf of Albania, Argentina, Armenia, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Chile, Croatia, Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Guatemala, Honduras, Ireland, Iceland, Italy, Jordan, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Maldives, Malta, Mexico, Monaco, Montenegro, Morocco, the Netherlands, Nigeria, Norway, Peru, Poland, Portugal, the Republic of Korea, the Republic of Moldova, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Saint Kitts and Nevis, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Tunisia, Turkey, Ukraine, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the United States of America and Uruguay), Ireland (on behalf of the European Union, Albania, Armenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Georgia, Iceland, Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova, Serbia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Ukraine), Japan, Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of);

(b) Representatives of observer States: Algeria, China, Colombia, Cuba, Denmark, Morocco, Norway, Russian Federation;

(c) Observers for international organizations: Council of Europe, Organization of Islamic Cooperation;

(d) Observers for non-governmental organizations: Canadian HIV/AIDS Legal Network, Centre for Human Rights and Peace Advocacy, China Society for Human Rights Studies, Chinese People's Association for Peace and Disarmament, Human Rights Advocates Inc., Human Rights House Foundation, Indian Council of South America, International Association of Jewish Lawyers and Jurists, International Association of Schools of Social Work, International Buddhist Relief Organisation, International Commission of Jurists, International Muslim Women's Union (also on behalf of the World Muslim Congress), International Service for Human Rights, Japanese Workers' Committee for Human Rights, Nord-Sud XXI, Liberation, Organisation pour la communication en Afrique et de promotion de la cooperation conomique internationale - OCAPROCE Internationale, Rencontre africaine pour la dfense des droits de l'homme, Reporters Without Borders International, United Nations Watch, World Barua Organization.

314. At the 32nd meeting, on 13 March 2013, statements in exercise of the right of reply were made by the representatives of China and Cuba.

E. Consideration of and action on draft proposals

Contribution of parliaments to the work of the Human Rights Council and its universal periodic review

315. At the 48th meeting, on 21 March 2013, the representative of Ecuador introduced draft resolution A/HRC/22/L.21, sponsored by Argentina, Ecuador, Italy, Maldives, Morocco, Romania and Spain and co-sponsored by Australia, Austria, Bolivia (Plurinational State of), Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Chile, Colombia, Cuba, Cyprus, Djibouti, El Salvador, Estonia, Ethiopia, Finland, France, Georgia, Germany, Guatemala, Honduras, Ireland, Lithuania, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Peru, Poland, Portugal, the Republic of Moldova, Slovakia, Switzerland, Thailand, Turkey, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Uruguay and Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of). Subsequently, Algeria, Angola, Azerbaijan, Brazil, Burkina Faso, the Congo, Cte dIvoire, Egypt, Indonesia, Iraq, Malta, Montenegro, the Republic of Korea, Rwanda, Senegal, Slovenia, the United States of America, Ukraine, Zimbabwe and the State of Palestine joined the sponsors.

316. At the same meeting, the representative of Ecuador orally revised the draft resolution.

317. In accordance with rule 153 of the rules of procedure of the General Assembly, the attention of the Council was drawn to the estimated administrative and programme budget implications of the draft resolution. The Chief of OHCHR Programme Support and Management Services made a statement in relation to the budgetary implications of the draft resolution as orally revised.

318. At the same meeting, the draft resolution, as orally revised, was adopted without a vote (for the text as adopted, see part one, chapter I, resolution 22/15).

Promotion and protection of human rights in post-disaster and post-conflict situations

319. At the 48th meeting, on 21 March 2013, the representative of Uruguay introduced draft resolution A/HRC/22/L.23, sponsored by Uruguay and co-sponsored by Angola, Bolivia (Plurinational State of), Bosnia and Herzegovina, Cameroon, Chile, the Congo, Costa Rica, Cte dIvoire, Djibouti, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Estonia, Georgia, Germany, Guatemala, Honduras, Namibia, Nigeria, Norway, Panama, Peru, Portugal, Sierra Leone, Slovakia, Spain, Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of) and the State of Palestine. Subsequently, Argentina, Burkina Faso, Croatia, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ethiopia, Iraq, Ireland, Luxembourg, Maldives, Montenegro, Morocco, the Philippines, Poland, Romania, Rwanda, South Sudan, Tanzania, Timor-Leste, Togo, Tunisia, Uganda, Ukraine and Zimbabwe joined the sponsors.

320. At the same meeting, the draft resolution was adopted without a vote (for the text as adopted, see part one, chapter I, resolution 22/16).

 

 

VI. Universal periodic review

321. Pursuant to General Assembly resolution 60/251, Human Rights Council resolutions 5/1 and 16/21, Council decision 17/119 and Presidents statements 8/1 and 9/2 on modalities and practices for the universal periodic review process, the Council considered the outcome of the reviews conducted during the fourteenth session of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review held from 22 October to 5 November 2012.

A. Consideration of the universal periodic review outcomes

322. In accordance with paragraph 4.3 of Presidents statement 8/1, the following section contains a summary of the views expressed on the outcome by States under review, Member and Observer States of the Council, as well as general comments made by other relevant stakeholders before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary.

Czech Republic

323. The review of the Czech Republic was held on 22 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by the Czech Republic in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/CZE/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/CZE/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/CZE/3).

324. At its 34th meeting, on 13 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of the Czech Republic (see section C below).

325. The outcome of the review of the Czech Republic comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/3), the views of the Czech Republic concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group (see also A/HRC/22/3/Add.1).

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

326. The Czech Republic clarified that it had received a total of 136 recommendations during the review. It considered them carefully and had a thorough discussion thereon. The Government Commissioner for Human Rights also organized an expert meeting, during which representatives of civil society, including the members of the Government Council for Human Rights and its committees, discussed all the recommendations and related topics. The outcome of the discussions was also uploaded on the webpage of the Government Commissioner for Human Rights.

327. After a careful analysis, the Czech Republic decided to accept 129 recommendations and not to accept 7 recommendations. It recognized that many recommendations addressed important human rights issues and drew attention to various problematic areas. It underlined that many of the recommendations had already been addressed by the existing national strategies and consequently were fully or partially implemented. This was the case of the recommendations in the area of social integration of the Roma minority, inclusive education, and fight against human trafficking, rights of the child, gender equality and inclusion of foreigners.

328. The Czech Republic confirmed that other recommendations would be included in its present or future national strategies as an important source of inspiration. It further underlined that many recommendations would be implemented continuously as part of the general human rights policy such as the recommendations regarding the ratification of international treaties or the human rights protection framework.

329. The Czech Republic elaborated that the reason that 7 recommendations did not enjoy its support was due to the fact that their implementation was not envisaged by the country. With regard to the recommendations to ratify the International Convention of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of Their Families and the connected ILO Convention No. 189, ILO Convention No. 169, as well as the Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the Czech Republic clarified that it always acted with high responsibility when accepting and entering into international obligations. Hence, it always carefully analyses the concordance of the national legal order with the international treaty and its general impact on it before it enters the obligation and ratifies the treaty.

330. With respect to the issue of corporal punishment, the Czech Republic clarified that the law prohibited corporal punishment of children in all public institutions as schools and child-care facilities. Parents or foster parents may only use upbringing methods that are appropriate, should respect the childs dignity and not endanger his or her development. Excessive corporal or other punishment in the family is prohibited and sanctioned by law. It went on to clarify that as non-excessive corporal punishment is at present not negatively perceived, its sudden general prohibition would hardly be effectively enforceable and a recommendation with such aim could not be effectively implemented. At the same time, the Czech Republic emphasized that it would increase the sensitivity of the general public to corporal punishment of children and to promote alternative methods of positive parenting without violence. Based on the results of these activities, the Czech Republic would reconsider if and when the corporal punishment of children in the family can be completely prohibited.

331. The Czech Republic clarified that it made a thorough investigation of its involvement in the CIA rendition flight programme at the request of the Secretary-General of the Council of Europe in 2006, which revealed no involvement of Czech public officials in acts amounting to breaches of the prohibition of torture or cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment of any other international obligation of the Czech Republic.

332. The Czech Republic further clarified that it issued a standing invitation to the Special Procedures in 2000 and since then, it was fully prepared to cooperate with them and to provide any necessary support and assistance to their work.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

333. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of the Czech Republic, eight delegations made statements.

334. Belarus regretted that the Czech Republic refused to ratify the ICRMW, ILO Conventions Nos. 169 and 189 and the Palermo Protocol. Belarus remained concerned about discrimination against migrant workers and the extent of human trafficking in the Czech Republic and called on the Czech Republic to pay special attention to these issues. Belarus also noted that the Czech authorities refused to carry out along with the Special Procedures of the Human Rights Council a comprehensive and transparent investigation into the alleged involvement of the CIA secret programmes on arbitrary detention and secret rendition of suspects who may have been subjected to torture. Belarus also noted that the Czech Republic failed to provide specific facts or evidence, which would prove that such an investigation has been carried out. Belarus called on the Czech Republic to cooperate with the Human Rights Council and its Special Procedures and particularly to implement the recommendation no. 41 by organising, as a matter of priority, visits of the Special Rapporteurs on torture, human trafficking and migrants and the Independent Expert on minority issues to the country, having in mind its standing invitation extended to them.

335. Botswana welcomed the approach of the Czech Republic to outline its position on all recommendations, including those that did not enjoy its support. Botswana also welcomed the undertaking made by the Czech Republic to produce a voluntary interim report on the implementation of the UPR recommendations.

336. Cuba noted continuing manifestations of racism and xenophobia expressing concern about reports of several incidents of violence and incitement to hatred. Cuba regretted that the Czech Republic did not prohibit organizations that incite racial discrimination. Cuba also noted reports of an increase in prison overcrowding, which would have resulted in an increase in violence among prisoners and the number of suicides. Cuba reiterated the recommendations to develop a comprehensive national action plan to combat and prevent racism, racial discrimination, xenophobia and intolerance in line with the Durban agreements; to prohibit organizations that incite hatred, racism, racial discrimination and xenophobia; to overcome gender stereotypes that perpetuate discrimination against women; to increase the representation of women, including Roma, in legislature, government and public Administration, particularly in senior positions; and to take steps to reduce prison overcrowding.

337. The Islamic Republic of Iran expressed concern that Roma persons are the main target of hate crimes and legal provisions remain inadequate to support them. It also expressed concern about violation of the Roma childrens right to education. Further, it stated that law enforcement officials should be empowered to support effectively child victims of commercial sexual exploitation and to protect them against future exploitation.

338. Morocco welcomed the commitment of the Czech Republic to provide a voluntary interim report on the implementation of the UPR recommendations. Morocco also noted with satisfaction legislative measures taken, which will open the door for the ratification of a number of international treaties. Morocco also welcomed the ratification of the Convention on the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearance and the future creation of the Supreme Judicial Council to strengthen the independence of the judiciary.

339. The Republic of Moldova noted with satisfaction the integration of a gender perspective into the UPR follow-up process as a result of which all government policies are evaluated from gender equality perspective. The Republic of Moldova praised the progress made in combating human trafficking and child trafficking by emphasizing prevention measures. The Republic of Moldova also welcomed that the Czech Republic pledged to submit a mid-term report on the implementation of the UPR recommendations.

340. Romania noted the positive developments made in the period between the two UPR cycles, in particular the adoption of anti-discrimination legislation and the national plan for inclusive education.

341. While welcoming that the Czech Republic accepted the majority of the recommendations, Algeria wished to see that the Czech Republic would reconsider its position on the accession to the International Convention of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of Their Families. Algeria also looked forward to the ratification of the two first optional protocols to the CRC (OP-CRC-SC and OP-CRC-CAC) in the nearest future. Algeria wished to receive a reply on the recommendation to adopt a comprehensive national action plan on the prevention of racism, racial discrimination, xenophobia and intolerance.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

342. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of the Czech Republic, two other stakeholders made statements.

343. Amnesty International expressed concern that Roma children continue to experience widespread and systematic discrimination in education noting that various international human rights bodies, including the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination and the Commissioner for Human Rights of the Council of Europe made recommendations to the Czech Republic that it take concrete de-segregation measures. These recommendations mirror the 2007 judgment of the European Court of Human Rights that the Czech Republic violated the right of Roma children to an education free from discrimination by placing them in special schools offering a lower quality education. Amnesty International urged the Czech Republic to confirm its commitment to ending discrimination against children in education and to urgently implement the reform necessary to ensure that the thousands of Roma children can enjoy equal right to education.

344. The Open Society Institute regretted that the commitment of the Czech Republic made during the UPR Working Group in October 2012 to shutting down practical schools had not been explicitly reflected in its new education policy presented to the Council of Europes Committee of Ministers in December 2012. It further stated that the continued maintenance of a separate education system that segregates both Roma children and children disabilities away from their mainstream peers and educates them according to a limited curriculum undermined inclusive education goals for both sets of children. It urged the Czech Republic to collect data disaggregated by ethnicity, gender and disability in practical schools and in segregated classes set up in mainstream schools to allow for more effective assessments of progress towards de-segregation and inclusion.

Concluding remarks of the State under review

345. The Czech Republic concluded by saying that it deeply valued all the constructive remarks and suggestions, which will be reflected, when it comes to implementing the recommendations and planning its future human rights strategies and policies, including a new concept for Roma inclusion, and all the new complex strategies on education which will include chapters on inclusivity and equal opportunities. It confirmed that the national strategy on the rights of the child would continue to be implemented, so would the strategies on the rights of persons with disabilities, equal opportunities, and combat against trafficking or integration of foreigners. The Czech Republic also informed the Human Rights Council that it had adopted strategies for positive ageing (2013 – 2017), which deals with the issue of population ageing and the human rights of the elderly. The Czech Republic reiterated its commitment to the effective work of the UPR mechanism and reconfirmed its pledge to submit a voluntary progress report on the implementation of the UPR recommendations.

Argentina

346. The review of Argentina was held on 22 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Argentina in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/ARG/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/ARG/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/ARG/3).

347. At its 34th meeting, on 13 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Argentina (see section C below).

348. The outcome of the review of Argentina comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/4), the views of Argentina concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group (see also A/HRC/22/4/Add.1).

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

349. The delegation of Argentina recognized that the UPR was an opportunity for constructive dialogue with the members of the Council and Observer States to address the Argentine human rights situation.

350. Argentina hold its second UPR bearing in mind the commitment and responsibility that defined the mechanism as a tool for strengthening the capacity of the State in the promotion and protection of human rights and, therefore, conducted a broad consultation for the preparation of the national report. The report presented the evolution and development achieved in the promotion and protection of human rights since the first review in 2008, when the mechanism was just being established.

351. Argentina received 119 recommendations, which were carefully studied by the appropriate authorities. Of these, 89 were accepted, 17 were noted, 9 rejected and 4 had become abstract. Addendum 1 provided for explanations and answers. The accepted recommendations referred to a number of topics such as memory, truth and justice; domestic violence; gender; sexual and reproductive rights; the eradication of poverty; and migration.

352. The delegation expressed satisfaction at the significant number of recommendations recognizing the public policies that were being implemented, and reiterated the government's aspiration to further improve the human rights situation to meet the concerns reflected during the review.

353. The delegation recalled that Argentina had also has made several voluntary commitments. For instance, Argentina pledged to continue working to enhance the complementarity between sub-regional, regional and international mechanisms for the protection of human rights, and develop institutional mechanisms for the implementation of the decisions of these regional and international organizations, with the participation of civil society.

354. With regard to the reform of the Treaty Bodies, Argentina had pledged to continue working on their strengthening, with a special emphasis on improving accessibility for victims of human rights violations, and in strengthening participation and interaction opportunities for civil society organizations.

355. Argentina had also reaffirmed its commitment to continue working for the adequacy of the United Nations Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners to international human rights law; to promote initiatives to improve the standards of protection of the rights of migrants, and to lead discussions on the development and implementation of public policies in this area.

356. Argentina had also agreed to cooperate in an international campaign to promote the ratification of the Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.

357. Finally, Argentina was committed to continue promoting the necessary reforms aimed at the full realization of the right of access to information, and to continue with the design of a medium of articulation and dialogue between the Federal State and the provinces, and of these between them, for the promotion and protection of human rights.

358. In concluding, the delegation stated that the way in which the national report was prepared; the consideration and response to the recommendations received; and the voluntary commitments undertaken reflected not only the importance that Argentina conferred to the UPR mechanism, but also the importance ascribed to the respect, protection and promotion of human rights, on the conviction that it was essential in order to achieve a more just and egalitarian society.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

359. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Argentina, five delegations made statements.

360. Cuba acknowledged the progress achieved in implementing the recommendations accepted during the first cycle and highlighted positive constitutional and legal changes. It noted the increased participation of women in all areas and the measures taken to combat violence against women. In the field of labour and social security, Argentina reached, in 2011, the highest level of employment in history and took steps towards universal social security coverage. The delegation thanked Argentina for accepting the recommendations put forward by Cuba.

361. Malaysia expressed its appreciation for the transparent constructive and forthcoming engagement of Argentina in the UPR process. It was pleased with the responses provided by Argentina concerning the Governments commitment to human rights and its ratification of almost all international human rights instruments. Malaysia recognised that challenges remained on the issues of trafficking of persons and compliance of the ratified instruments. It was aware of the need for Argentina to be afforded the necessary time to continue making improvements in the area of human rights.

362. UNICEF welcomed the high level of attention paid by the Government to the analysis of each of the recommendations received and the endorsement of most recommendations related directly or indirectly to child rights. Recommendations related to the Ombudsman for Children, an intensified work against violence affecting children and a thorough implementation of the Convention on the Rights of the Child and attuned legislations across all provinces were noticed as areas where UNICEF would offer a strengthened cooperation altogether with the other United Nations agencies.

363. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela recognized the cooperation of the Government with the UPR. Argentinas intervention presented the successful plans to increase the living standards of the population, and explained the implementation of a project that had transformed the structures of society. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela stressed the drastic reduction of poverty and the process of democratization of information and communication, with new legislation that had positioned freedom of expression as a social right, and where the state had intervened to regulate the monopolistic concentration of the media.

364. Algeria congratulated Argentina for accepting most of the recommendations it received, knowing that several of the others were considered as already implemented. Algeria noted the acceptance of the recommendations it put forward to Argentina. The delegation felt that the realization of all human rights required a long-term project and acknowledged that Argentina had come a long way in this area since the end of military dictatorship.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

365. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Argentina, seven other stakeholders made statements.

366. Amnesty International called on the State to redouble its efforts to further promote the UPR and strengthen the human rights universal and regional systems. It noted that Argentina had accepted recommendations on the right to sexual and reproductive health of women, in particular, on reducing maternal mortality and access to legal abortion for rape victims. It regretted that Argentina continued criminalizing abortion in certain circumstances and invited Congress to incorporate in the 2013 legislative agenda a debate on this topic. It noted the rejection of recommendations 99.111 and 112 concerning the right to property, access to housing, education and participation of indigenous peoples. Indigenous communities continued to face threats of eviction, and cited the example of the community "La Primavera" in the town of Toba Qom, in the province of Formosa.

367. IIMA and VIDES welcomed the positive participation of Argentina during its second review. Regarding discrimination against vulnerable children, they were concerned that the poorest young children of indigenous origin suffered de facto discrimination, and could not enjoy equal opportunities in access to education and work. On sexual exploitation and trafficking, they observed that there were a high number of child victims of such practices. On the right to adequate housing and access to clean water, they were concerned that Argentina did not accept recommendation 99.111. They recommended to ensure the effective implementation of recommendations 99.1 and 99.21 related to the combat against all forms of discrimination; to take steps to implement the recommendations from sexual exploitation and human trafficking, eradicating corruption and the involvement of public officers; and to take the appropriate measures to eliminate discrimination against indigenous and peasant communities.

368. Save the Children International considered that juvenile justice should be a priority in Argentina. It recalled that the Committee on the Rights of the Child had expressed concern about the need to reform the juvenile justice system. Law 22.278 failed to distinguish between children in need of care and protection and children in conflict with the law. It, therefore, called the Government to comply with UPR recommendation 13 of 2008. Regarding the full recognition of sexual and reproductive health rights, it requested Provincial health authorities to adopt and implement the technical guidance for the comprehensive care of legal abortions and to train staff at all public health centres in the country on the scope, framework and implementation of the technical guidance.

369. Franciscans International and its partners in Argentina were encouraged that the Government had accepted one recommendation regarding indigenous peoples rights to participation and consultation in policies that affected them. Its implementation would imply guaranteeing this right in every legislative act or plan. They regretted the rejection of 3 related recommendations, asserting that current policy efforts were already adequate. The proposed reform process to unify the Civil and Commercial Codes, which the Government cited in its response, ignored the current state of law on collective rights and had not included consultation and participation components. Indigenous rights demanded adequate legal mechanisms and deserved to be regulated accordingly. Regarding accepted recommendations on disadvantaged sectors, they highlighted the vulnerability of communities by the expansion of the so called soy frontier. The use of deforestation, transgenic seeds and chemical pesticides had devastating impact in local communities.

370. Action Canada for Population and Development acknowledged that the Government had accepted the recommendations on sexual and reproductive rights. It regretted, however, that Argentina was failing to reduce maternal mortality and morbidity, and violence against women. The arguments for the autonomy of the provinces and the conscientious objection of health professionals should not affect the State's commitment to reduce these problems. The Integral Sexual Education Act was still not being implemented throughout the country. It urged the Government to take all necessary measures to fully implement the Comprehensive Sexuality Education Act nationwide.

371. The Association for the Prevention of Torture (APT) welcomed the establishment of the National System for the Prevention of Torture. It urged the authorities to implement, as soon as possible, the law that created the National Committee for the Prevention of Torture, taking safeguards to ensure that the process of selection and appointment of its members to be transparent, open and include the participation of civil society. APT stressed the importance that the State allocate the Committee with the necessary resources to perform its duties. It also noted the announcement of a number of strategies to improve the situation of prisons in Argentina.

372. The Centro de Estudios Legales y Sociales (CELS) recognized the establishment of the National Mechanism for the Prevention of Torture and hoped for the prompt appointment of its members. Argentina received recommendations requesting the Government to expedite the delivery of land titles to indigenous communities, and regarding the duty to enforce the Supreme Court ruling on access to free and legal abortion in cases of rape. CELS highlighted other outstanding issues that were not addressed during the review: the need to regulate the National Mental Health Act; the need for the judicial branches of the country to comply with the obligation to investigate and punish those responsible for acts of torture and State violence; and the need to harmonize national legislation on forced evictions with the international standards, to ensure due process and avoid criminalizing the homeless.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

373. The delegation thanked all parties involved in this process, especially the States and civil society organizations. Then, the delegation responded to some of the concerns that arose during the interventions.

374. Regarding indigenous peoples, the State had defined and surveyed 365 communities in 20 provinces. In a gradual process, a total of four million five hundred thousand hectares of indigenous community property lands had been recognized in several provinces. In addition, 72 legal services were implemented to defend communities in land conflicts, some 14,000 evictions were prevented and expropriation laws were implemented at the rate of 678,000 hectares, approximately.

375. Regarding comments on human trafficking, on 19 December 2012, the Chamber of Deputies adopted, in a special session convened by the Executive, an amendment to the law on trafficking, already approved by the Senate. The bill extended the sentences for the crime of sexual exploitation to between 2 and 4 years of imprisonment and established sentences of between 5 and 15 years of imprisonment when the victims were pregnant or minors.

376. On gender violence, on 14 November 2012, the Chamber of Deputies passed into law an amendment to the Penal Code establishing life imprisonment to men who, as a result of gender violence, killed a woman or a person who perceived herself as pertaining to the female gender. This penalty also applied to men who killed a transgender person. Also, the Attorney Generals Office recently created a program on gender policy, based on the need for effective equality between genders.

377. With regard to torture, the delegation welcomed the comments received on the recent establishment of the national preventive mechanism and added that, as of 20 March 2013, the Public Defenders Office would officially launch a campaign against torture covering various educational, training and awareness raising activities. The International Congress against Torture, to be held on 6 and 7 June 2013, was one example of these activities.

378. The delegation concluded by reaffirming Argentinas will to move forward, progressing and making the necessary changes in order to further improve the situation of human rights protection in the country.

Gabon

379. The review of Gabon was held on 23 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Gabon in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/GAB/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/GAB/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/GAB/3).

380. At its 34th meeting, on 13 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Gabon (see section C below).

381. The outcome of the review of Gabon comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/5), the views of Gabon concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group.

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

382. The Delegation of Gabon stated that during the interactive dialogue Gabon received 115 recommendations out of 105 were accepted. Gabon welcomed encouragements received by Members of the Human Rights Council regarding progress achieved in implementing the Universal Periodic Review recommendations of the first cycle, in 2008. Gabon further indicated that efforts made in promoting and protecting human rights could not be spared of criticism and observation, which are considered by Gabon as an appeal, an invitation, to do better.

383. Regarding the implementation of recommendations, Gabon indicated that progress had been made since October 2012 in the following areas: i) human rights national institution ii) education in human rights to prevent torture and inhuman treatment, iii) economic, social and cultural rights and improving living conditions of people.

384. Regarding the National Human Rights Commission, which was recently established, Gabon indicated that regulatory reforms were undertaken aiming at the compliance of the National Human Rights Commission with the Paris Principles. Gabon noted that, since January 2013, the National Human Rights Commission had its headquarters and had also enjoyed an increase of its budget, compared to previous years, allowing it to fulfill its mission.

385. In the framework of education in human rights, Gabon launched, on 10 December 2012, at the Central Prison of Libreville, a national campaign for the prevention of human rights violations of persons placed in detention. Gabon added that this campaign aimed at strengthening the notion of ethics, among professionals in the justice system, to prevent acts, such as torture, inappropriate or illegal investigation methods, and arbitrary or illegal detentions.

386. In March 2013, in Libreville, Gabon had also organized, in collaboration with the United Nations Centre for Human Rights and Democracy in Central Africa, a capacity building workshop on human rights (detention, trafficking in persons and migrations) for 40 police and gendarmerie officers.

387. Gabon indicated that regarding the administration of juvenile justice, the rights of the child had been incorporated in the curricula of the National School Magistracy.

388. Considering the recommendation on strengthening the implementation of economic, social and cultural rights and improving the conditions of life of the population, Gabon was engaged in a vast process of reforms aiming at making Gabon an emerging country by 2025. Actions were taken in different fields, such as the consolidation of the rule of law, strengthening democracy in a participatory basis, good governance and the fight against corruption and the protection of vulnerable people.

389. Gabon noted that the commitment with vulnerable populations had resulted in the establishment of institutions, such as: the National Human Rights Commission; the National Observatory for Childrens Rights; the National Observatory for protection of Familys Rights; the National Observatory for Women Rights and Parity and the National Social Aid Fund. The latter one had been endowed by almost 4 million U.S. dollars to contribute, among others, to programs supporting disadvantages persons, young people, persons with disabilities and orphans.

390. As part of the integration of elderly in the development process, Gabon introduced a mechanism that ensures free medical coverage for the elderly as well as the creation of an old age minimum basket. This mechanism also provides prenatal free health care and maternal attention for all pregnant women infected with HIV.

391. Gabon had established a Grand Prize that reward each year women who were distinguished in their field of activities and a Project to support the Development of Microcredit in Gabon (PADMG) to empower women and fight against poverty. Gabon had also initiated social policies aimed at fighting against the spoliation of widows and improving their management in the financial fields.

392. Regarding the recommendations on ratification of international instruments namely: i) the 1954 Convention relating to the Status of Stateless Persons, ii) the 1961 Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness and iii) the International Convention of All Migrant Workers and Members of their Family, Gabon had set up an ad hoc inter-ministerial commission to inventory the international instruments on human rights that Gabon had not yet ratified. The report of this Commission would allow Gabon to initiate the process of ratification in the Parliament.

393. Concerning the recommendation on the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court, Gabon established in 2012 a commission for the reform of the Criminal Code whose mission is to integrate into national law the provisions of the international instruments, including the Convention against Torture, the Geneva Convention of 1949 and the Rome Statute.

394. The Delegation indicated that Gabon will take all appropriate measures to implement the UPR recommendations.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

395. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Gabon 11 delegations made statements.

396. Togo appreciated Gabon commitment to promote and protect human rights. Togo took note with satisfaction of measures taken to strengthen the protection of vulnerable people and in particular women and children. Togo noted improvements in access to health and education and the participation of women in political life. Togo encouraged Gabon to continue its efforts made since 2009 in the social and economic fields. Togo wished Gabon success in implementing recommendations.

397. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela appreciated the cooperation and commitment of Gabon with the Universal Periodic Review mechanism as well as efforts made by Gabon to prepare its national report with participation of all sectors. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela noted that Gabon accepted the majority of the recommendations made during the second cycle. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela also noted with satisfaction the progress made by Gabon on the ratification of international human rights instruments and the steps undertaken to consolidate the National Human Rights Commission in accordance with the Paris Principles. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela highlighted the commitment of Gabon to increase school enrolment rate and to improve the equipment at different levels of education. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela encouraged Gabon to continue strengthening its social policies to improve living conditions of its people for which purpose the support of the international community is essential.

398. Algeria welcomed that Gabon accepted a large number of recommendations, including those made by Algeria on strengthening human rights education and training programs for law enforcement officials and also in at stepping up combat the phenomenon of ritual crimes. Algeria was encouraged by progress made by Gabon in different areas such as: right to education and health; protection of children; strengthening the national human rights institution framework; the ratification of international instruments and the cooperation with human rights mechanisms. Algeria reiterated its appeal to strengthen international cooperation to consolidate Gabon efforts.

399. Botswana welcomed the decision by Gabon to accept many of the recommendations. Botswana was encouraged that Gabon took on board recommendations relating to the possibility of reviewing legislation regarding discriminatory practices against women, as well as, adopting measures to guarantee access to birth registration of all children. Botswana applauded Gabon for its commitment to the work of the Council and particularly as a member of the Council and as Coordinator of the African Group.

400. Burkina Faso welcomed the second Universal Periodic Review report of Gabon and took note with interest of the update provided by Gabon on the implementation of recommendations. Burkina Faso commended the cooperation of Gabon with the Council, in particular with respect to the Universal Periodic Review as it was reflected by the large recommendations accepted by Gabon. Burkina Faso encouraged Gabon to continue its dynamism in implementing the recommendations.

401. Cte dIvoire congratulated Gabon for the recommendations accepted that will contribute to the consolidation of the Rule of Law and the respect of human rights. Cte dIvoire noted with satisfaction Gabons commitment to work for peace and stability not only in its territory but also in the sub-region as well as on the whole continent. Cte dIvoire welcomed Gabons successful involvement in the resolution of the crisis in Central Africa. Cte dIvoire invited the international community to support Gabon.

402. Cuba congratulated Gabon for the spirit of cooperation with the Council as well as for starting implementing the accepted recommendations of the first Universal Periodic Review cycle. Cuba noted that the Government and civil society had launched measures, such as, the establishment of the National Human Rights Commission, the establishment of NGO networks and the execution of strategies to fight against insecurity, among others. Cuba added that Gabon had made steps to prohibit gender discrimination practices. Cuba welcomed public policies on education, trafficking in persons, children rights and persons with disabilities. Cuba thanked Gabon for accepting its recommendation.

403. Morocco congratulated Gabon on having accepted more than 90 per cent of the recommendations. Morocco welcomed Gabons commitment to strengthening the framework and national policies for the promotion and protection of human rights. Morocco applauded the constructive interaction between Gabon and the Universal Periodic Review mechanism as it was shown by the acceptance of almost all of the recommendations. Morocco took note that Gabon continued efforts to align its legislation with its obligations, in particular combatting trafficking in persons. Morocco also noted that Gabon had taken legislative measures to strengthen the national legal arsenal concerning protection of children from mistreatment. Morocco congratulated Gabon for the quality of its work as coordinator of the African Group for questions of human rights.

404. The Republic of Moldova welcomed Gabons commitment to the Universal Periodic Review mechanism. It congratulated Gabon on preparing its national report as well as with the participation of governmental organisations and civil society. It praised Gabon on the progress made in ensuring gender equality, in particular in the areas of access by women to health, education and employment. The Republic of Moldova expressed satisfaction over the measures that Gabon had adopted to protect children and prevent childrens trafficking and economic exploitation. It welcomed that Gabon accepted a large number of recommendations, including the one made by the Republic of Moldova.

405. South Africa commended the commitment of Gabon to the Universal Periodic Review mechanism and the processes thereof. South Africa acknowledged the consultative processes undertaken during the preparations for the Universal Periodic Review and encouraged that this approach be continued when implementing the accepted recommendations for the second cycle. South Africa commended the acceptance of 105 recommendations as well as the explanations provided in relation to the recommendations which did not enjoy the support of Gabon. South Africa thanked Gabons continued cooperation and constructive participation in the Universal Periodic Review process.

406. The Sudan welcomed Gabons commitment with the Universal Periodic Review as it was shown during its participation in the interactive dialogue. The Sudan also appreciated the openness of Gabon and the participation of the civil society during the drafting process of the national report. The Sudan praised Gabon for having accepted a large number of recommendations including the one made by the Sudan regarding education, training and research. The Sudan called upon the international bodies to cooperate with Gabon and to facilitate the strengthening capacity. The Sudan wished Gabon success and progress.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

407. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Gabon one stakeholder made a statement.

408. Rencontre africaine pour la dfense des droits de lhomme (RADDHO) took note of Gabons commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights. It welcomed efforts of Gabon regarding death penalty, the adoption of a law on minorities rights and the ratification of the Rome Statute as well as the integration of women in the field of work. RADDHO encouraged Gabon to continue its efforts to apply constitutional guarantees regarding freedom of expression and press. RADDHO indicated that Gabon needs to eliminate trafficking in persons by expanding the legislation to cover all the victims. RADDHO also noted the persistence of ritual crimes and exhorted Gabon to make double efforts to put an end to this practice and sanction the perpetrators. RADDHO noted the need of adequate measures regarding the punishment of domestic rape and the establishment of a legal framework to defend womens right.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

409. The Delegation of Gabon reiterated its commitment with the Universal Periodic Review mechanism and praised the Human Rights Council efforts to strengthen the national human rights protection and promotion mechanisms.

410. Regarding the issues of ritual murders and trafficking in persons, Gabon indicated that the Special Rapporteur on trafficking in persons visited Gabon in 2012 and will present her report during the twenty-third session of the Human Rights Council in June 2013. At this opportunity, Gabon would indicate the progress made in this field. Gabon further stated that its legislation had focused on child trafficking but efforts were undertaken to extend the legislation to trafficking in persons.

411. Concerning ritual crimes, Gabon stated that the criminal code recognizes crimes of blood. Gabon had asked the Commission for the reform of the Criminal Code to introduce in the Criminal Code the issue of ritual crimes. Gabon will inform on the progress made on the implementation of the related recommendation.

412. Gabon reiterated that freedom of the press yes but violation of the law no. However, Gabon had also requested the Commission for the reform of the Criminal Code to ensure that members of the press or the media, who are accused of violating the ethics code of the press, could not be immediately subjected to deprivation of freedom. Efforts in this sense had been made by Gabon. Finally, the Delegation indicated that Gabon wants development based on the respect of human rights and the environment.

Ghana

413. The review of Ghana was held on 23 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Ghana in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/GHA/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/GHA/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/GHA/3).

414. At its 35th meeting, on 14 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Ghana (see section C below).

415. The outcome of the review of Ghana comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/6), the views of Ghana concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group.

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

416. The delegation of Ghana expressed its appreciation to the States who participated in its review last year for their invaluable contributions and constructive comments. It also appreciated the Troika—Angola, Norway and Qatar—and the Secretariat for their support extended to it during the review process.

417. As stated by the then Deputy Attorney-General at Ghanas review last year, the Government of Ghana views the UPR mechanism as an important platform to examine the human rights situation in the country, to assess governments performance in promoting and protecting the rights of its citizens, and to share and exchange views on addressing its weaknesses. Promotion and protection of human rights is a continuous and unending process, and Ghana is committed to ensure that the institutions charged with that responsibility are further strengthened to carry out their mandates effectively. The peaceful transition of power following the successful conduct of Presidential and Parliamentary elections on 7 December 2012, and the fact that Ghana has undertaken six peaceful presidential and parliamentary elections and transfer of power since 1992 demonstrates the importance of strong national institutions in its evolving democracy.

418. At Ghanas last review, 76 states actively participated in the interactive dialogue, and a total of 148 recommendations were made. Out of this number, 123 enjoyed the Governments support and were accepted. These related mainly to the promotion of women and childrens rights, ensuring the effective implementation of the Domestic Violence Act, further strengthening of judicial and anti-corruption measures, and combatting harmful traditional practices and combatting trafficking in persons. Others concerned improving detention and prison facilities, sanctioning of Police brutalities, strengthening the capacities of the Commission on Human Rights and Administrative Justice (CHRAJ), and the ratification of a number of conventions to which Ghana is signatory.

419. Twenty five of the recommendations, however, did not enjoy the support of Ghana. They related to two major issues, namely: 1) the abolition of the death penalty; and 2) decriminalization of same sex relations between consenting adults. While Ghana provided a detailed response to these issues during the review last October, the delegation reiterated Governments position on these issues.

420. The issue of the death penalty is an entrenched provision in the Constitution which can only be changed through a referendum by the people of Ghana. The decision to establish a moratorium on the death penalty or to abolish it rests with the people. The Government therefore cannot impose an immediate official moratorium or take any decision on the death penalty prior to the referendum. While the Government is cognizant of initiatives at the international level and in various fora calling for the abolition of the death penalty, it will be bound and guided by the outcome of the referendum. The acceptance by the Government of the recommendation of the Constitutional Review Commission regarding the death penalty demonstrated its commitment to let the opinion of the people be heard. It may be noted, in this connection, that there have been no executions in Ghana since 1993.

421. With regard to the recommendations on decriminalization of same sex relations between consenting adults, the delegation reiterated that Ghana does not have a policy of non-equal treatment of its citizens and any acts of violence perpetrated against any manner of persons in Ghana is investigated and appropriately dealt with. The Deputy Attorney General and Deputy Minister of Justice clearly articulated this during his presentation of the national report last year as follows, The Constitution of Ghana entrenches the fundamental principles of non-discrimination and equality. It also guarantees the freedom of religion and the rights of persons to practice that religion. The Constitution also provides for the legislation to enact laws that further the social cohesion and economic development of the people of Ghana. Admittedly, laws passed by Parliament are a reflection of the sovereign wishes of the people they represent. Unless and until an issue, be it social, religious, economic or political is sufficiently advanced in the moral consciousness of the citizenry and an unequivocal demand is made on Parliament to address the issue through effective legislation, any attempt to bypass the true wishes of the people will be counter-productive.

422. Ghana attaches great importance to the work of the thematic Special Procedures of the Human Rights Council and is one of the States that have extended standing invitations to the thematic mandate holders to visit Ghana. In 2011, government representatives and other stakeholders had fruitful interactions with the Special Rapporteur on the Right to Health during his visit to Ghana in May 2011. Invitations to the Special Rapporteur on contemporary forms of slavery, the Special Rapporteur on Torture, and the Working Group on the issue of human rights and transnational corporations and other business enterprises to visit Ghana sometime this year are also under consideration.

423. Ghana expressed its appreciation to all delegations who took the floor for their constructive comments, views and kind words. It also thanked all the civil society organizations for their participation. It took note of all their concerns and assured that the Government will make every effort to implement the recommendations which lie within its purview. The delegation reaffirmed the commitment of Ghana to uphold human rights in the country. To this end, the Government shall continue to consult with all stakeholders in the country to ensure that respect for the human rights in Ghana is further improved and advanced, and remains an inclusive process.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

424. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Ghana, 11 delegations made statements.

425. Togo took note of the progress made in the fight against domestic and gender-based violence as well as in access to justice, the rights of the detainees, administration of land and the fight against HIV/AIDS. Togo encouraged Ghana to continue with its policies for socio-economic development, particularly those aimed at improving the quality of education and health services for the population.

426. Viet Nam congratulated on the remarkable efforts and progress made by Ghana in socio-economic development as well as promotion and protection of human rights. Being also a developing country facing a number of difficulties, Viet Nam supported and encouraged Ghana to make further efforts to promote its socio-economic development and human rights not only in Ghana but also throughout the world.

427. Algeria appreciated that Ghana had accepted a large number of the recommendations, including those from Algeria. During the review of Ghanas national report, Algeria highlighted the tangible efforts made by Ghana through a programme of institutional strengthening. Ghana committed itself to, inter alia, strengthening its policies for the advancement of women and eliminating laws which are discriminatory against women, and also promoting childrens rights.

428. Botswana stated that, as a developing country, it appreciated the challenges that accompany implementation of accepted recommendations. It is also appreciative of Ghanas decision to take on board recommendations relating to the possibility of ratifying additional instruments related to the rights of the child, as well as additional measures to advance the rights of women. It looked forward to learning from Ghana on its on-going process to complete the drafting of the national human rights action plan.

429. Cte dIvoire noted with satisfaction Ghanas determination to cooperate with the United Nations human rights mechanism as well as its commitment to work for the peace and stability not only in the country but also in the sub-region. This is demonstrated by its responsible involvement and effective management of the recent crisis in Cte dIvoire as well as its support and cooperation to facilitate (international) judicial procedures on-going in Cte dIvoire.

430. Cuba appreciated the contributions made by Ghanas Constitutional Review Commission. Ghana has taken huge strides forward in connection with domestic violence, gender-based violence, access to justice, the rights of detainees, and the land administration. It also highlighted the progress made in combating HIV/AIDS. Cuba is grateful that its recommendations were accepted to continue to implement strategies for socio-economic development, in particular, the importance of guaranteeing education and good quality health services to the entire population, as well as applying programmes and measures to reduce, and, ultimately, eradicate HIV.

431. Gabon stated that a strict observation of 123 recommendations made to Ghana demonstrates that Ghana is on the right track. The rights of women and children, improvement and access to health care, education for all, access of the most vulnerable to the justice, these are the general framework in which the recommendations made to Ghana are to be found. Gabon encouraged Ghana to continue to implement the programme and measures to fight again HIV/AIDS and provide access to healthcare for all.

432. Morocco noted with satisfaction that Ghana, its fraternal country, took important measures, such as elaboration of a national plan of action for human rights and identification of five priority lines of action in order to face concerns related to human rights in a comprehensive and integrated manner. Morocco congratulated tangible will of Ghana to consider human rights as priority in its internal policy as well as implementation of laws and programmes which have a positive impact on the quality of life of Ghanaians.

433. The Philippines commended Ghana for its continuing commitment to implement measures to strengthen its policies for basic human rights, especially for women and children. It appreciated Ghanas commitment to protect the rights of migrant workers and welcomed Ghanas acceptance of its recommendation to consider ratifying ILO Convention no. 189 on Decent Work for Domestic Workers. It was also pleased of Ghanas acceptance of its recommendation to consider ratifying the Palermo Protocol on Trafficking in Persons.

434. South Africa stated Ghana remained steadfast in the quest to ensure the practical enjoyment of all human rights and fundamental freedoms by its citizens. It acknowledged Ghanas focus on ensuring equal rights for women, health and education, as well as ensuring the continued engagement of all relevant stakeholders in the promotion and protection of human rights.

435. The Sudan congratulated Ghana, its government and people, for organizing presidential elections last December and stated that peoples participation clearly reflected Ghanas commitment and openness to the new democratic process. It congratulated the new President, John Dramani Mahama, and wished him every success in his new mission. The Sudan noted with satisfaction acceptance of its two recommendations and hoped that these recommendations would serve to support Ghanas commitment to human rights.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

436. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Ghana, seven other stakeholders made statements.

437. Human Rights Watch stated that there is a significant number of serious human rights abuses in psychiatric hospitals, where people with mental disabilities face involuntary admission and arbitrary and prolonged detention, and inadequate conditions, including overcrowding, poor hygiene, forced seclusion, among others. In prayer camps, people with mental disabilities are chained – sometimes outdoors – and denied food and medication and adequate shelter. It recommended that Ghana act immediately to take the steps to improve conditions in public psychiatric hospitals by: ensuring adequate food, shelter and health care; and by prohibiting practices of beating patients, prolonged seclusion, and arbitrary detention and treatment; monitor prayer camps and other non-orthodox mental health service providers to ensure that individuals are not held against their will, subjected to forced fasting or chaining, or denied access to appropriate health care; develop the necessary legislative instrument to implement the new mental health law as a priority; and prosecute inhumane practices, including torture, in psychiatric hospitals and prayer camps.

438. Amnesty International welcomed Ghanas support of recommendations to improve conditions and to reduce overcrowding in prisons. Nevertheless, overcrowding is severe, sanitation inadequate, and food supplies and medical care scarce. It urged Ghana to give immediate effect to these recommendations. It was also very disappointed at Ghanas rejection of recommendations to decriminalize same-sex relations, and to combat the climate of homophobia and discrimination against Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) persons. Furthermore, it noted that there was only one reference to the issue of housing in the review, although this is an issue that deserved much more attention. It called on Ghana to issue a moratorium on mass evictions until legal and procedural safeguards are in place, in line with international human rights standards.

439. Edmund Rice International Limited remained concerned at the high school drop-out rates and the unequal access to quality education, particularly for vulnerable children and those in the north of the country. It was also concerned at the growing incidence of drug and alcohol addiction among adolescents. It called on Ghana to establish programmes to ensure the full participation in education and employment of vulnerable children; develop programmes to close the gaps in educational resources and educational achievements between children from the north and south of the country; establish a Task Force to work closely with the police in bringing to justice those who exploit children; address the underlying issues of poverty and child abuse and neglect, which lead to the exploitation of vulnerable children; and promote health education programmes targeting children and youth, with a focus on healthy lifestyles, reducing drug and alcohol abuse, and suicide prevention.

440. Verein Sudwind Entwicklungspolitik was deeply concerned about the high number of child labour, some as young as five years old at E-Waste dumps, where they are engaged in work which is dangerous and threatening to their health. It encouraged Ghana to give special attention to protect these children and their families from violations of their right to health and to reinforce its efforts to provide health care and medical assistance for these children and their families. It also urged Ghana to pay closer attention to prevent illegal import of e-waste and to consider it an offensive crime in line with the Basel Convention. It recommended that Ghana ratify the Optional Protocols to the Convention on the Rights of the Child and adopt a national action plan to prevent child labour.

441. Association for the Prevention of Torture (APT) welcomed Ghanas commitment to ratify the Optional Protocol to the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment during the Universal Periodic Review (OP-CAT) during the review last October, however, recalled that Ghana made the same commitment four years ago during its first UPR. APT also noted that, in 2011, the Committee against Torture recommended that Ghana accelerate the ratification process, as well as the designation of a national preventive mechanism. APT encouraged Ghana to ratify OPCAT by the end of the year and take prompt measures to designate a national preventive mechanism. It welcomed Ghanas statement that a visit of the Special Rapporteur on Torture is under consideration and encouraged Ghana to take full advantage of this opportunity to move forward on torture prevention.

442. World Vision International welcomed the recommendation from Luxembourg, calling upon Ghana to redouble efforts to ensure the protection of the rights of women and children and highlighted the need to protect children from all forms of violence and abuse, including social and economic exploitation. It called on Ghana to expedite efforts to establish a telephone hotline for child victims and informants in centralized areas and to examine how this can eventually be established in the more remote areas of the country. It also welcomed the recommendations made by Hungary and Bulgaria concerning equal access to education in all parts of the country, however, indicated that, for the particular situation of girls in the north, it will be crucial to address the cultural practice of fostering these girls into domestic servitude which effectively ends their education and leaves them in situations of exploitation and abuse.

443. Rencontre africaine pour la dfense des droits de lhomme (RADDHO) stated that, the last general election, which was peaceful, free, and fair, is an ample testimony that confirms that Ghana is a model of democracy in West Africa. It acknowledged Ghanas efforts in continuing to engage with the National Human Rights Institution and the civil society. It was particularly encouraged by the passage of the Domestic Violence Act and the establishment of the Domestic Violence Secretariat. It was also pleased to know that Ghana is exerting its efforts to address the gaps in its human rights framework and develop a national Human Rights Action Plan. It, however, voiced its deep concern about the continuing practice of Female Genital Mutilation and the ongoing violence against women in the rural areas. It called on Ghana to enhance its efforts in the campaign to stop traditional practices affecting women in the rural areas and to take action by implementing laws to that end. Police brutality is also an issue that Ghana must address without delay. It encouraged Ghana to promote human rights education in all spheres of the society, such as the promotion and awareness of human rights education in the police force.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

444. Ghana once again expressed its appreciation to all delegations and civil society organizations who took the floor for their contributions and participation. A new Government assumed office in January 2013 in Ghana. The new administration has indicated its readiness to constitute an inter-ministerial committee to examine the recommendations accepted by the previous Government to ensure their full implementation. In conclusion, the delegation reiterated the commitment of the Government of Ghana to uphold human rights in the country. It also looks forward to continued cooperation with the Human Rights Council and all other human rights mechanisms.

Ukraine

445. The review of Ukraine was held on 24 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Ukraine in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/UKR/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/UKR/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/UKR/3) and (A/HRC/WG.6/14/UKR/3/Corr.1).

446. At its 35th meeting, on 14 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Ukraine (see section C below).

447. The outcome of the review of Ukraine comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/7), the views of Ukraine concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group (see also A/HRC/22/7/Add.1).

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

448. The delegation stated that Ukraine has immensely benefited from the constructive engagement of the States Members of the United Nations through their recommendations and questions put forward during the interactive dialogue that took place in the working group of October 2012. The delegation acknowledged the important role of the Human Rights Council, and in particular the universal periodic review mechanism in ascertaining and measuring the member-States accomplishments in the protection and promotion of human rights. Ukraine has been committed to ensuring the long term success of the mechanism.

449. The delegation informed that the relevant state bodies were consulted and views of the civil society actors were taken into account in deliberating Ukraines position on all recommendations. The truthful assessment of the countrys available resources and the capacity for implementation of the recommendations received was also an important criterion in the decision making process. After the careful consideration, the Government decided to accept 114 out of 145 recommendations received and partially accept 4 recommendations. Ukraine was not in a position to accept 27 recommendations. Ukraines position to all recommendations with detailed explanations was provided in the addendum to the working group report.

450. The delegation highlighted that some recommendations were not supported because it was unlikely that the Government could ensure the implementation of obligations set in those recommendations until the next review. For example, the ratification of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court required the Constitutional amendments.
