At the same time, the Government fully acknowledged that non-acceptance of the recommendations did not mean stopping to work on the human rights issues addressed in those recommendations. In the first cycle of the universal periodic review, for example, Ukraine did not initially support recommendations to ratify the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and its Optional Protocol. However, Ukraine ratified both documents during the period under the review.

451. The delegation provided further information on the Governments reasoning on the rejected recommendations, which could be subdivided into a few main groups. First group of rejected recommendations concerned the ratification of several international human right instruments (recommendations nos. 97.1, 97.2, 97.3, 97.4, 97.5, 97.6, 97.8, 97.9, 97.10, 97.11, 97.13, 97.14 and 97.15). A comprehensive legal analysis and an assessment of financial, economic and socio-political implications of the implementation of any international legally binding document should precede the ratification process. Therefore, delegation explained that the non-acceptance of those recommendations would not impede the possibility of the ratification of those human rights instruments but rather has initiated a national process to carefully study the possibility of their ratification.

452. The delegation also informed that Ukraine ratified, in January 2013, the Convention Relating to the Status of Stateless Persons and the Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness. In spite of it, Ukraine could not support the recommendation no. 97.11 as it also suggested the ratification of the Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence.

453. Another group of non-accepted recommendations referred to non-discrimination of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people and persons belonging to national minorities (recommendations nos. 97.18, 97.19, 97.25, 97.44, 97.71, 97. 72 and 97.73). The delegation explained that the new legislation established the principle of non-discrimination and guarantees equal rights, freedoms and opportunities to all persons, equality before the law and the respect of the dignity for everyone. Moreover, the Government has continued improving this legislation in line with the relevant standards of the European Union.

454. In respect to recommendations nos. 97.113 and 97.114, delegation expressed its view that every person has enjoyed the right for fair public trial before the impartial tribunal in Ukraine. As to the recommendations nos. 97.143, 97.144 and 97.145 concerning the protection of refugees and asylum seekers the delegation explained that non-refoulement principle was enshrined in the domestic legislation.

455. The delegation informed that a working group has been established under the auspice of the Ministry of Justice with the aim to develop an effective follow-up mechanism, including an action plan for the implementation of the recommendations received during the review. The working group has comprised representatives of relevant state bodies and non-governmental organizations. The Government has highly valued the participation and contribution of the representatives of the civil society in the early stages of the review process, namely in carrying out an objective assessment of the human rights situation before being reviewed and it has been committed to continue the established cooperation with the civil society during the follow-up process.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

456. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Ukraine, seven delegations made statements.

457. The Russian Federation stated that the review of Ukraine in the second cycle demonstrated once again the commitment of Ukraine to improve its national human rights mechanisms. It commended Ukraine for accepting a large number of recommendations put forward during the review. The Russian Federation noted with regret that Ukraine did not support its recommendation to take measures to prevent integration of nationalistic ideas in the platforms of political parties. However, the Russian Federation noted the explanation provided by Ukraine that Article 37 of the Constitution explicitly ban the promotion of violence and the incitement of racial and ethnic hatred by political parties. Therefore, the Russian Federation called on Ukraine to continue taking steps to prevent violation of the above mentioned constitutional provision.

458. Uzbekistan commended Ukraine for providing detailed responses and clarifications regarding recommendations put forward during the review. It noted with appreciation that Ukraine accepted two recommendations put forward by Uzbekistan and that Ukraine adopted legislation to reform the judiciary and improve criminal procedures as well as strengthen tolerance in the society and develop strong legal and institutional basis for the protection of the rights of children.

459. Algeria commended Ukraine for its cooperation and engagement with the universal period review mechanism. It noted with appreciation the acceptance by Ukraine of the majority of the recommendations received, including two recommendations put forward by Algeria regarding the equal participation of women in decision making and combating human trafficking.

460. Cuba noted with satisfaction the efforts made by Ukraine to combat discrimination and the process of the adoption of a new comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation. It highlighted the efforts and commitments of Ukraine to promote gender equality in various fields of life. Cuba noted that several measures had been implemented by Ukraine to combat domestic violence, including the development of the National Action Plan in this regard and prevent a sale of children. Cuba noted with appreciation the acceptance by Ukraine the recommendations put forward by Cuba regarding rights of child, in particular their access to education and health as well as combating racism and xenophobia.

461. The Islamic Republic of Iran noted that six out of seven recommendations that it put forward during the review was accepted by Ukraine. It expressed hope that the Government takes legal and effective measures to implement those recommendations, in particular the recommendations regarding the identification of child victims of commercial sexual exploitation and combating racial discrimination and xenophobia.

462. The Philippines noted with appreciation the acceptance by Ukraine the recommendations on the adoption of the anti-discrimination law and the allocation of adequate resources for the implementation of the Act on Combating Trafficking in Persons that were put forward during the review by the Philippines. The Philippines was concerned but understood the rationale for unwillingness of Ukraine to accept another recommendation put forward by the Philippines regarding the ratification of the International Convention for the Protection of the Rights of Migrant Workers and their Families and the ILO Conventions no. 189 on Decent Work for Domestic Workers. However, it expressed hope that Ukraine will join in the efforts to setting up the global standard for protection of migrant workers.

463. Romania noted with appreciation the constructive engagement of Ukraine in the universal periodic review process, which demonstrated the Governments commitment in ensuring high human rights standards in the country. It noted the acceptance of all recommendations put forward by Romania and expressed its confidence that the next review would document progress in the implementation of those recommendations.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

464. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Ukraine, four other stakeholders made statements.

465. The Ukrainian Parliament Commissioner for Human Rights noted with appreciation the acceptance by Ukraine of a large number of recommendations put forward during the second cycle of the review. Drawing the attention of the Government to the issue of domestic violence, the Commissioner called on Ukraine to ratify the Council of Europes Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence.

466. Amnesty International welcomed the acceptance by Ukraine of the recommendations on torture and police impunity as well as the protection of the rights of migrants and the respect of the principle of non-refoulement. At the same time, Amnesty International noted with regret the rejection by Ukraine of the recommendations to guarantee full respect for freedom of expression relating sexual orientation and protect lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people from discrimination. Non-acceptance of those recommendations contrasted starkly with the acceptance by Ukraine of more than 15 recommendations on non-discrimination more generally. In 2012, the Parliament passed its first reading of a draft law which would ban any production of publication deemed to promote homosexuality. Amnesty International called on Ukraine to reject this law on the grounds that it would result in discriminatory treatment of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.

467. Federatie van Nedralndse Verenigingen tot Integratie van Homoseksualiteit - COC Nederlandsand commended Ukraine for supporting several recommendations made during the review. At the same time, it noted with regret that Ukraine did not accept recommendations nos. 97.18, 97.19. 97.25, 97.57, 97.70, 97.71 and 97.73 to further safeguard the protection of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI) people against discrimination. It noted with concern an increase in violence against LGBTI people and pending draft laws aimed to limit basic human rights for LGBTI people that are pending for the decision of the Parliament. COC Nederlandsand called upon the Government inter alia to ensure the full protection of LGBTI people against any form of discrimination, including sexual orientation and gender identity in the anti-discrimination legislation and refrain from adopting homophobic bills pending before the Parliament.

468. Human Rights Watch noted with regret that Ukraine rejected over a dozen recommendations to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity and to drop homophobic laws. Despite protections enshrined in the Constitution, LGBT people remained discriminated and stigmatized and there had been a growing number of attacks targeting LGBT-related events and activist. It called on the Government to, inter alia, speak out against the homophobic laws currently pending before the parliament and ensure effective investigations into acts and threats of violence against members of the LGBT community. Human Rights Watch welcomed Ukraines acceptance of three recommendations on the right to health and expressed its hope for implementation of those recommendations by the Government.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

469. The delegation stated that the Government has acknowledged human rights challenges facing the country and has been committed to persevere diligently to address them. Ukraines efforts in human rights have continued to be based on the principles of the universality, indivisibility, non-discrimination and equality of human rights. The delegation expressed its firm belief that dialogue with the UN member states in this global forum motivated the Government to stay focused and self-critical in its efforts and prompted to seeking for possible effective improvements.

Guatemala

470. The review of Guatemala was held on 24 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Guatemala in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/GTM/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/GTM/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/GTM/3).

471. At its 35th meeting, on 14 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Guatemala (see section C below).

472. The outcome of the review of Guatemala comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/8), the views of Guatemala concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group (see also A/HRC/22/8/Add.1).

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

473. Guatemala highlighted that, during its second UPR, it received 138 recommendations, accepted 111 and noted 27. Guatemala also made five voluntary commitments.

474. Guatemala indicated that the Commission of Indigenous Communities is in favour of accepting the competence of CERD under Article 14 of the Convention (100.1 to 100.4 and 100.7). The question counts with the favourable opinion of the Commission and is currently before the plenary of Congress which will decide on the matter.

475. The death penalty (100.5 and 100.11) has not been applied for more than ten years. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has initiated a consultation process on its abolition, as well as on the 3rd Optional Protocol to the CRC (100.8).

476. Guatemala continues its efforts to merge the Presidential Secretary of Peace with the Presidential Human Rights Commission (COPREDEH) and the National Compensation Programme (100.10), in order to avoid duplicity with respect to human resources and budget. Decentralized coverage will be strengthened and extended.

477. Regarding recommendations 1001.12 and 100.13 related to the Law against Femicide, Guatemala has increased the budget allocation to the Public Prosecutors Office, Judiciary and Ministry of Interior. A specialized court was created and operates 24 hrs/day and the institutionality has been reinforced for the implementation of the law.

478. Regarding recommendations on the internal armed conflict (100.16 and 100.7), Guatemala pointed out that in 1996 an amnesty law was negotiated between the Government and Guerilla groups, with the participation of United Nations. Questions about the scope of exceptions set out in the law should be addressed by the Judiciary and the Constitutional Court.

479. Regarding recommendation 100.6 on the Rome Statute, harmonization of domestic legislation is being addressed by the Guatemalan Coalition for the International Penal Court, which is composed of civil society, state bodies, and international organizations and elaborates legislative proposals.

480. Regarding Guatemalas voluntary commitment to develop a programme to protect journalists (100.14, 100.15 and 100.18), a specialized technical body was composed by the Ministry of Interior, National Civil Policy, Public Prosecutor, COPREDEH and NGOs. The Ombudsman has been requested to establish an institutional mechanism to receive complaints and to call on the Ministry of the Interior and COPREDEH to agree on protection measures with respect to each case.

481. Regarding recommendations on indigenous peoples (100.9, 100.19 - 100.27), the Constitution of Guatemala establishes that subterranean, hydrocarbon deposits and minerals belong to the State and cannot be considered private property. Its exploitation is determined by the public utility and necessity. Concessions and licences are granted in accordance with international and national legislation on environmental protection and benefits to local communities.

482. Regarding ILO Convention No. 169, a session was held between government cabinet, OIT officials and representatives of the Peruvian government, the only country that counts with a legal regulation on indigenous people consultations. Procedures and milestones have been established for the preparation of the law and rules.

483. Evictions only take place pursuant a judicial decision. An action protocol is being prepared, to ensure that actions of the Public Prosecutor, judges and national police are carried out with full respect of legal and international human rights instruments.

484. There are no indigenous territories in Guatemala. However, there are state lands, lands belonging to communities and cooperatives, and individual or collective private property, which are regulated by a legal framework.

485. A national follow-up system has been designed, and a mechanism to disseminate UN reports and recommendations has been put in place.

486. The International Human Rights Forum facilitates the preparation of reports and statistics on the accomplishment of recommendations made to Guatemala in 2003. Guatemala will submit an annual internal assessment of the recommendations implemented.

487. Guatemala shared other countries concerns at armed violence and violent deaths, in particular among young people.

488. The agreement on Security, Justice and Peace involves different actors, sharing responsibility between the different sectors and the State, covering the following areas: institutional, programmatic, operative and of incidence. Different measures have been taken to protect the rights of young people, such as the National Policy (2010-2020), the creation of the National Council, Advisory Council for the Youth, Vice-Ministry of Prevention of Violence and Crimes and Commission on Prevention of Violence with Arms. The Prevention Communitarian Unit against Violence has been strengthened, and police officers have also been trained on prevention. The bill on destruction of fire arms was also drafted.

489. Guatemala also referred to the creation of the Ministry of Social Development and the my safe neighbourhood programme, through which youngsters and their families carry out activities such as risk assessment and recuperation of public spaces as well as leisure activities. This has resulted in a substantive reduction of violent deaths.

490. The young protagonist programme allowed 55,000 youngsters to participate in development activities, including 470 workshops for almost half a million youngsters in vulnerable situations. The initiative includes a grant programme to facilitate their incorporation into the formal labour market.

491. Guatemala referred to the prevention of harassment and violence at school and safe school programmes, as well as to measures taken to coordinate the implementation of various programmes, such as the specific unit for youth, and the departmental and municipal commissions. In the voices for peace concert, 20,000 youngsters participated.

492. The observatory of violent deaths 24-0 promotes a culture to stop violent deaths with the support of social networks.

493. The Law against Femicide has brought about the establishment of different judicial specialized bodies. Trained personnel have been allocated to these courts to ensure specialized access to justice for women. They are established in different regions and have interpreters in different Mayan languages. A specialized court works 24 hours to receive declarations, authorise urgent investigations and grant security measures.

494. Guatemala referred to the preventive approach to implement strategic multi-sectorial measures, aimed at reducing the causes of violence and to empower women as right holders. The Presidential Secretary of Women (SEPREM) has articulated efforts from ten governmental institutions.

495. The Women Unit coordinates and advises at presidential and ministerial levels, and participates in designing public policies for women and promoting womens issues.

496. The Ministry of Interior designs the National Policy to Prevent Violence, including the Strategic Plan on Prevention of Violence against Women (2013-2016).

497. SEPREM collaborates with the Municipal Office for Women, implementing the Pacts on Security allowing the development of partnerships with governmental bodies and NGOs.

498. Statistical data on violence against women are collected from the three State powers in order to obtain realistic numbers, allowing the deployment of objective and reliable data base.

499. A budget classifier was created as a tool to institutionalize the rights of women.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

500. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Guatemala, six delegations made statements.

501. Cuba highlighted the strengthening of national institutions, in particular the creation of the Ministry of Social Development. It noted measures and programmes that are being implemented to combat gender violence and that the fight against poverty is a priority in Guatemala. It also noted programmes to guarantee the right to food, education and health to which Cuba will continue cooperating. Cuba also noted measures regarding indigenous peoples rights and thanked Guatemala for having accepted its recommendations.

502. Gabon noted Guatemala efforts regarding the protection of the rights of women and combating violence against women, such as the Law against Femicide. Gabon encouraged Guatemala to take preventive measures and to sanction violence, exploitation and trafficking. It invited Guatemala to implement the recommendation related to gender equality and indigenous womens rights. It recommended that the international community assist Guatemala in implementing the recommendations received.

503. Morocco noted with satisfaction that Guatemala accepted more than 80 per cent of the recommendations received and that those recommendations are followed up by the Presidential Human Rights Commission. Morocco also noted that Guatemala will submit a mid-term review as well as its voluntary commitments related to the preparation of programmes to prevent violence, protection of journalists and the rights of women.

504. The Philippines commended Guatemalas commitment to implement measures to strengthen its policies for vulnerable groups such as women and children. It noted with appreciation Guatemalas acceptance of its recommendations, in particular increasing the budget allocation to implement the Law against Femicide. They also noted that Guatemala will consider ratifying ILO Convention 189 on Decent Work for Domestic Workers and the 2nd Optional Protocol of ICCPR on the abolition of death penalty.

505. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela noted the progress made during the 16 years of democracy and peace experienced by Guatemala. It appreciated Guatemalas willingness to redefine its institutional human rights system. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela also highlighted Guatemalas efforts in the area of women rights, in particular through the National Policy of Promotion and Comprehensive Development of Women and the Equal Opportunities Plan (2008-2023). The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela also noted with satisfaction the establishment of the Ministry of Social Development.

506. Algeria noted with satisfaction that Guatemala accepted a high number of recommendations, in particular the two recommendations made by Algeria related to the right to food and violence against women. It also noted that Guatemala has reinforced its legislative and institutional framework and appreciated actions taken to promote economic, social and cultural rights, in particular those living in poverty and extreme poverty.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

507. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Guatemala, nine other stakeholders made statements.

508. The Human Rights Ombudsman of Guatemala stated that the judicial system continues to face structural failures, such as the penitentiary system. He recognized the strengthening of the public prosecutor institution and the ratification of the Rome Statute as a step forward. He regretted the violent deaths of women and noted the alarming femicide rate. He shared the observations made by the Special Rapporteur on the sale of children and child prostitution that Guatemala should move to a comprehensive and coordinated approach to protecting children. He also noted that the regulation of consultation with indigenous peoples is still pending and was concerned about social conflicts related to mining activities and at the lack of dialogue with the communities concerned.

509. Amnesty International (AI) was concerned at the refusal of the military to release key documents relating to military operations conducted during the internal armed conflict. AI noted that it is not clear from Guatemalas response if the recommendations related to impunity enjoy its support or not. According to AI, UN sponsored the Truth Commission, and its recommendation No. 47 was related to prosecution and punishment of those responsible for crimes under international law. AI called on Guatemala to ensure that no one responsible for crimes under international law be granted an amnesty, and to implement the 2011 judgement of the Constitutional Court related to consultation with indigenous peoples.

510. COC Netherlands acknowledged the adoption of the Law against Femicide and congratulated Guatemala for accepting to take further necessary measures to protect LGBT persons. It was however concerned at the persistence of violence against women, including lesbian women. It also noted the high number of cases of femicide, and that only two per cent of cases lodged before courts end in convictions. It urged Guatemala to establish mechanisms to inform and create awareness on the rights of LGBT persons, in particular lesbian women, promote their integration and combat violence based on sexual orientation and gender identity.

511. International Commission of Jurists (ICJ) was concerned at the lack of meaningful consultations in Guatemala with indigenous peoples in the case of  megaprojects, that they have been forcefully evicted from places where these projects are put in place and that, where consultations have taken place, authorities have not respected the outcome of those consultations. ICJ called on Guatemala to take steps to ensure that its legislation and practice conform to ILO Convention No. 169 and to ensure that amnesties and clemency do not apply in cases of gross human rights violations. ICJ regretted that the steps taken are not effective and the abuses perpetrated against human rights defenders continue without prompt, independent and impartial investigations.

512. Action Canada welcomed Guatemalas acceptance of the recommendation to strengthen the protection and integration of LGBT people. It stated that Guatemala should supplement measures related to violence against women and discrimination against transgender women. It recalled that, according to IACHR, killings against trans-women in Guatemala are part of a serious situation of violence and lack of investigation, and that the State is obligated to investigate those crimes and sanction those responsible. It urged Guatemala to record and investigate all murders and violence based on gender identity or sexual orientation and to take all necessary measures to protect the rights of LGBT people.

513. Association for the prevention of torture (APT) regretted delays in establishing a national mechanism to prevent torture (MNP) in Guatemala, and urged Congress to achieve a transparent and adequate selection process of MNP members. APT stressed the importance of providing the new mechanism with necessary resources to carry out its activities in an independent and efficient manner. APT also urged Guatemala to implement the Penitentiary Law and rules and to criminalize torture in its domestic law in line with article 1 of the CAT.

514. Plan International, Inc. (PI) welcomed Guatemalas efforts to protect childrens rights and the acceptance of many recommendations. It noted that Guatemala is still the country with the least investment on children in Latin America. PI called on Guatemala to increase budget allocation for children and adolescents in order to ensure adequate training for personnel, fight against chronic malnutrition of children, and ensure to all children access to quality health services. PI appreciated Guatemalas willingness to consult with civil society in the UPR process.

515. Human Institute for Co-operation with Developing Countries (Hivos), while acknowledging progress in addressing serious human rights violations in the past, noted obstacles coming from government officials. According to Hivos, reconciling the past also implies that Guatemala respects and protects the rights of indigenous peoples. It was also concerned that, by denying recognition of indigenous territories, the State enables land and natural resources evictions. Hivos stated that, according to UDEFEGUA, two thirds of attacks against HR defenders are against those who defend the rights of indigenous peoples. It recalled that Guatemala has the duty to protect them and ensure that companies also respect their rights.

516. Lutheran World Federation was concerned that Guatemala denies recognition of indigenous territories, which deprives indigenous peoples from the possibility of the State implementing comprehensive policies based on a territorys cultural values and identity. They were also concerned that this lack of recognition may lead to land evictions and deprivation of natural resources. They urge that prior to the approval or adoption of any law or rule, Guatemala guarantee prior consultation with the indigenous peoples concerned. They recommended Guatemala take into consideration the report of the Special Rapporteur on indigenous peoples.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

517. Guatemala thanked States and NGOs for their comments, which will enrich the human rights policies through the national follow-up system, established at the National Presidential Human Rights Commission. Guatemala will submit periodic information on progress and measures taken regarding recommendations accepted and voluntary commitments.

Benin

518. The review of Benin was held on 31 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Benin in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/BEN/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/BEN/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/BEN/3).

519. At its 36th meeting, on 14 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Benin (see section C below).

520. The outcome of the review of Benin comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/9), the views of Benin concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group.

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

521. The delegation of Benin recalled that during the interactive dialogue, 129 recommendations had been formulated, 123 had been accepted of which eight had already been implemented, five had been rejected and one had been under consideration.

522. It stated that the various reforms and policies initiated by Benin since its first Universal Periodic Review in 2008 had showed the obvious will of the Beninese authorities to work daily for the promotion and protection of the human rights.

523. The Delegation underlined that since its second review, on 31 October 2012, Benin had undertaken actions in respect of its international commitments. These actions are the following:

(a) Adoption of the law on the establishment of the National Commission of Human Rights in December 2012;

(b) Bringing into compliance the Code of Criminal Procedure with regard to the removal of the provision on the death penalty;

(c) Adoption by the National Assembly, in January 2013, of the new land code in order to secure investments;

(d) Strengthening of the fight against ritual infanticide through advocacy in collaboration with international and national Non-Governmental Organizations as well as introduction into the childrens code, currently under study in the National Assembly, of the relevant provisions to eradicate all these practices.

524. The delegation also noted that other initiatives had been planned in the short, medium and long-term, for the implementation of the accepted recommendations. It added that these measures would be the subject of a mid-term report which would be submitted in a timely manner.

525. The delegation stated that regarding the only pending recommendation concerning the ratification of the Kampala amendments of the Rome Statute, consultations were taking place to sign this protocol as soon as possible.

526. With regards to the five rejected recommendations concerning the decriminalization of homosexual relations between consenting adults, the delegation highlighted that during the interactive dialogue, it had pointed out that the phenomenon was marginal in Benin and that no court had prosecuted or punished for such acts. Given the current state of the positive law and certain endogenous factors, it would be difficult to consider immediately the decriminalization of such acts. Nevertheless, the issue is valid and will be treated with due attention.

527. The delegation reiterated Benins willingness to continue to respond favourably to formal requests for visits and provide its full cooperation to the mandate holders.

528. The delegation noted that Benin wished to rely on international cooperation for the implementation of the accepted recommendations. Beninese authorities are convinced that human rights are a factor contributing to social cohesion, stability and peace and with the support of all; they will succeed in furthering a real culture of human rights.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

529. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Benin, 12 delegations made statements.

530. Cuba noted that since its last review, Benin had been dedicated to strengthening its legal and institutional framework of promotion and protection of human rights and had continued to harmonize its domestic law with the international instruments it was part of. It also noted the efforts undertaken to advocate on the necessity to eradicate the harmful traditional practices which violate the rights of women and children. Cuba also stated that the fight against corruption and illicit enrichment, reinforced by the 2011 law, constituted a significant step. It also appreciated that Benin had accepted its recommendations.

531. Gabon welcomed the cooperation of Benin in the international procedures and mechanisms for the protection and promotion of human rights. It recognised Benins efforts to strengthen womens rights, in particular girls rights in the fields of education and health, and encouraged Benin to pursue its efforts in the implementation of advocacy programmes to eradicate female genital mutilation. Gabon also encouraged Benin to continue to take action in favour of free education at primary and secondary levels.

532. Morocco welcomed Benin's exemplary cooperation in the UPR framework. It supported the reforms undertaken by the Beninese authorities for the establishment of a legislative and political environment conducive to the development and enjoyment of human rights. Morocco encouraged Benin in its efforts to consolidate human rights, such as its adherence to the Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and its reform of the judiciary system. It also congratulated Benin on its policy of education for all and its action against poverty.

533. Romania noted, as a member of the troika during the last review of Benin, the seriousness with which Benin had approached the UPR process. It thanked Benin for its acceptance of most of the recommendations, including those on the protection of childrens rights and hoped that the legislation aimed at improving the legal framework of the protection of childrens rights would be adopted by the Parliament.

534. South Africa welcomed the large number of accepted recommendations for the second cycle of the UPR. It applauded the commitment of Benin to combating poverty and welcomed initiatives such as the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper and the Growth Strategy for Poverty Reduction. South Africa also appreciated the acceptance of its recommendations. Finally, it encouraged the international community to engage in cooperation with Benin as requested to advance the promotion and protection of all human rights in the country and overcome challenges as identified during the UPR process.

535. The Sudan was pleased to see the commitment undertaken by Benin with regard to UPR and that the country had been an active participant to the interactive dialogue. It noted that Benin had accepted 123 recommendations out of 129 formulated during its last review and that was a clear evidence of States commitment. The Sudan was very pleased of Benins acceptance of the recommendations to take executive and legislative measures to fight child labour, abuse and trafficking as well as to intensify efforts to fight against drug and alcohol addiction of children and promote awareness raising campaign in this regard.

536. Togo welcomed Benin for its acceptance of most of the recommendations addressed by the Working Group in October 2012. It noted with satisfaction Benins commitment to fulfil its international obligations and welcomed the efforts made in order to promote all human rights, in particular social, economic and cultural rights. Togo invited the international community to pursue its cooperation with the Beninese authorities in the implementation of the strategies and development plans and in poverty reduction.

537. UNICEF welcomed the efforts made by Benin to reduce infant mortality rate and promote gender equality in the education sector. It also welcomed the endorsement of the working groups recommendations to adopt the childrens code, promote free birth registration, and eliminate cultural practices such as child marriage, female genital mutilation and ritual infanticide. UNICEF called Benin to focus in particular on the victims of child trafficking, domestic child labour and corporal punishment in schools. It urged Benin to improve prison conditions and address the excessive length of pre-trial detention of children in conflict with the law. Finally, it called on Benin to ratify, among others, the Third Protocol to the Convention on the Child on Communications as well as The Hague Adoption Convention.

538. Algeria reiterated its satisfaction for the strengthening of the domestic legislative arsenal, in particular regarding the rights of handicapped people, free and transparent elections, good governance and fight against children's trafficking. It highlighted the importance of continuing the efforts to combat poverty and its support to the assistance requested by Benin from its partners. Algeria appreciated Benin's acceptance of its two recommendations.

539. Botswana commended Benin for the achievements made towards the promotion and protection of human rights, including, among others, the adoption of the Good Governance Charter, measures to address poverty reduction and gender equality. It noted with satisfaction efforts made to promote access to health care and the enactment of the law on corruption and illicit enrichment. Botswana noted that Benin reaffirmed, during its last review, its commitment to promote and protect human rights both at domestic and international levels.

540. Burkina Faso noted with satisfaction the efforts made in the implementation of the recommendations. It welcomed the full cooperation between the Beninese authorities and the mechanisms of the Human Rights Council. Burkina Faso encouraged Benin to pursue its dynamic of promotion and protection of human rights.

541. Cte dIvoire stated that Benin's commitment in the promotion and protection of human rights had favourable feedback in the African continent, in particular during its mandate at the head of the African Union. During this mandate, Benin worked resolutely for peace and stability not only in the country but also in the sub-region and the entire continent with a particular involvement in the resolution of the crisis in Mali. Cte d'Ivoire invited the international community to support Benin in the implementation of its commitments.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

542. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Benin, three other stakeholders made statements.

543. The Instituto Internazionale Maria Ausiliatrice (IIMA) and International Volunteerism Organization for Women, Education and Development – VIDES welcomed the accepted recommendations concerning education, but regretted that the school dropout rate had not been sufficiently addressed during the UPR. They recommended that Benin take measures to avoid children dropping out of school and to implement Article 24 of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Regarding the infanticide of witch children, they asked Benin to support the work of social services and NGOs which managed training centres for the reinsertion of these children. The two organisations also recommended that Benin continue its efforts to eradicate children's trafficking and elaborate a normative framework on cybercrime.

544. Concerned at the practices aimed at killing or excluding from the society children whose births were considered abnormal, Franciscans International (FI) recommended that Benin take more significant measures to make the all population sensitive on the harmful effects of certain rituals on the life and development of children. It noted that home births promoted infanticide as many births were not recorded. Furthermore, FI asked Benin to give a more precise definition of ritual practices in the draft of the Childs Code. Finally, FI asked Benin to strengthen the protection of surviving children by improving existing capacity, building shelters and developing an adequate legal and social protection of the children and mothers harassed and discriminated against by these practices.

545. Rencontre africaine pour la dfense des droits de lhomme (RADDHO) noted with satisfaction the establishment of the Mediator of the Republic institution; the increase of staff in the Judiciary; the building of new prisons, development of legislation on the prevention of violence against women and development of the legal framework for the fight against corruption and illicit enrichment. Significant efforts had also been made for education and access of all to health. However, RADDHO was concerned at the ineffectiveness of the police and judiciary to investigate ritual infanticide and children's trafficking; restriction of the right to strike; violence of security forces; length of pre-trial detention and conditions of detention. It also urged Benin to take measures to end the violence against witch children and to complete the adoption of the new Penal Code in order to provide a definition of torture that was in line with CAT.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

546. The delegation of Benin thanked the States for their statements of support and the organisations for their contributions. It stated that the various comments and observations would allow Benin to improve its policy of promoting and protecting human rights. The delegations also reiterated Benins commitment to the UPR as well as its commitment to continue its cooperation with all the mechanisms of the Human Rights Council.

Republic of Korea

547. The review of the Republic of Korea was held on 25 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by the Republic of Korea in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/KOR/1 and Corr.1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/KOR/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/KOR/3 and Corr.1).

548. At its 36th meeting, on 14 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of the Republic of Korea (see section C below).

549. The outcome of the review of the Republic of Korea comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/10), the views of the Republic of Korea concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group (see also A/HRC/22/10/Add.1).

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

550. The Republic of Korea thoroughly considered all the recommendations made by Member States during the Universal Periodic Review (UPR). Following the adoption of the UPR report on 31 October 2012, relevant Ministries engaged in active consultations, including with a number of human rights non-governmental organizations (NGOs), where participants expressed various opinions on the recommendations. Following those consultations, the recommendations were presented to the Sub-Council on National Human Rights Policy on 30 November 2012 and then to the National Human Rights Policy Council for discussion on 13 December 2012.

551. After thorough and careful deliberation, the Policy Council decided to fully accept 42 recommendations and to partially accept 1 recommendation out of a total of 70 recommendations. Clarification was also provided for those recommendations predicated on factual inaccuracy. Detailed information on the responses to all recommendations was submitted in January 2013 and has been made available on the OHCHR website.

552. Touching upon those responses, the Republic of Korea emphasized that the majority of recommendations related to equality and non-discrimination enjoyed the support of the Government, which primarily related to the rights of vulnerable groups, including persons with disabilities and migrants. The Government would continue to intensify its efforts to effectively protect the rights of those persons.

553. Most of the recommendations related to the rights of the child also enjoyed the Governments support. The Republic of Korea attached great importance to the protection of children and the Government would continue its endeavours to improve their rights

554. The Republic of Korea welcomed other important recommendations made, such as those relating to freedom of expression on the internet, the economic empowerment of women, the prevention of sexual harassment, the right to health and the social protection of refugees and migrant workers. The Republic of Korea would continue seeking ways to strengthen and improve relevant domestic laws, institutions and procedures in those areas.

555. Some recommendations did not receive the Governments support: either they required further examination or they presented difficulties at this time. By way of explanation, the delegation stated that the National Security Act was necessary for the States existence and security, given the unique security concerns of the Republic of Korea in terms of the division of the Korean Peninsula.

556. Regarding conscientious objection to military service, the delegation stated that the introduction of alternative service was difficult taking into account such factors as the special security situation, the procurement of military resources under a conscription system, the equal burden sharing of military duties and the lack of public consensus. The Government would examine those issues by taking into consideration any future changes in the security situation and the level of public consensus.

557. The Republic of Korea explained that the issue of the death penalty would remain under careful review through a comprehensive evaluation of public opinion and legal analysis, social circumstances, as well as further evaluation concerning the overall function of the death penalty in criminal policy.

558. The delegation emphasized that, if UPR were to be a credible mechanism leading to actual human rights improvements, effective follow-up measures were imperative. They should include mechanisms to promote implementation at the national level by providing a platform for national dialogue on human rights by various stakeholders: a crucial part of which was to provide an opportunity for public scrutiny of government policies.

559. The Republic of Korea committed to incorporating the recommendations that enjoyed its support into the Second National Action Plan for the Promotion and Protection of Human Rights. The recommendations that did not enjoy support at this time would also be considered for the future enhancement of the protection of human rights.

560. The delegation explained that, in the first half of 2013, the National Human Rights Policy Council would be convened to modify the Second National Action Plan in order to reflect and incorporate the UPR recommendations. Additionally, as occurred following the first cycle of the UPR, a working group for the follow-up of the UPR would be established within the Government and would annually report to the National Human Rights Council. The Government was also considering ways to consult with civil society in the follow-up process.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

561. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of the Republic of Korea 10 delegations made statements.

562. Malaysia thanked the Republic of Korea for its transparent, constructive and forthcoming engagement in the UPR process. Malaysia was pleased with the Republic of Koreas launching of the Second National Action Plan on human rights and in extending the investigatory scope of the National Human Rights Commission. The promotion of humanitarianism in the Republic of Koreas official development assistance programmes was lauded. Malaysia wished the Republic of Korea well in its future endeavours.

563. Algeria welcomed the Republic of Koreas acceptance of more than 60 per cent of the recommendations made to it, including some already implemented, as well as the recommendation made by Algeria on combating all forms of discrimination, including by strengthening the legislative framework. Algeria regretted that the recommendation made by eight countries to ratify the ICRMW was not approved. Republic of Korea was wished every success in implementing the recommendations made.

564. Botswana thanked the Republic of Korea for the update presented and commended the progress made since the first review, such as the withdrawal of the reservation under article 9 to the CRC and the development of policies in favour of persons with disabilities. According to Botswana, the review in October 2012 clearly demonstrated the Republic of Koreas continued cooperation in advancing human rights.

565. Cuba highlighted the actions taken by the Republic of Korea, including to promote the rights of women, engage in gender mainstreaming in State policies and to guarantee equal opportunities. Cuba was encouraged to see the Governments plans to draw up a general anti- discrimination law and would welcome further details in that regard. Cuba encouraged the Republic of Korea to continue exploring different ways and means to overcome the problems identified in its national report, including the ratification of international instruments and withdrawal of reservations as well as different topics related to the National Security Law. Cuba was pleased that its recommendations had been accepted by the Republic of Korea with respect to combating and preventing racism and racial discrimination and xenophobia, guaranteeing equal opportunities and pursuing programmes aimed at promoting and protecting economic social and cultural rights, particularly health, education and food.

566. The Islamic Republic of Iran thanked the Republic of Korea for its informative statement and welcomed the fact that the 5 recommendations it had made enjoyed the support of the Republic of Korea. It expected further efforts from the Government to improve the rights and conditions of migrant workers and expressed the hope that the the Republic of Korea would take effective measures to implement particular recommendations on defining the legal status for an independent child rights monitoring body and on children with disabilities.

567. The Lao Peoples Democratic Republic noted that the Republic of Korea had accepted a large number of recommendations and had taken the necessary steps for their implementation. It referred to commendable achievements such as the launching of the Second National Action Plan, the lifting of reservations to the CRC, the ratification of the CRPD and efforts to uphold the rights of disabled persons, to combat human trafficking, domestic violence and gender-based discrimination as well as the generous contribution to overseas development.

568. Viet Nam thanked the Republic of Korea for its detailed update of developments, including the serious consideration given to and effective implementation of recommendations since the review last October. It noted with appreciation the acceptance by the Republic of Korea of a high number of recommendations, including two recommendations made by Viet Nam, namely fostering the rule of law and social cohesion and intensifying policies and measures to guarantee the full enjoyment of rights, protection and welfare of migrant workers.

569. The Philippines was pleased at the Republic of Koreas serious effort to incorporate the accepted recommendations in its Second National Action Plan for the Promotion and Protection of Human Rights. The Philippines noted the Republic of Koreas commitment to consider those recommendations that it could not presently support for the future enhancement of the protection of human rights. The Philippines welcomed the acceptance of interim measures that are protective of the rights of migrant workers and their families. The Philippines expressed its optimism that the Republic of Korea would in the near future join the countries that have ratified ICRMW and ILO Convention No. 189.

570. The Republic of Moldova thanked the Republic of Korea for the complementary information on the UPR recommendations made to it. It commended the Government for ensuring effective gender equality in Government policies and the Governments commitment to prevent and prosecute domestic violence and ensure victims protection. It appreciated the Republic of Koreas acceptance of a significant number of recommendations, including those made by the Republic of Moldova.

571. Thailand appreciated the Republic of Koreas careful response to the UPR recommendations and for providing explanations for the recommendations not enjoying their support. The Republic of Korea was thanked for accepting Thailands recommendation on the promotion and protection of the rights of all migrant workers. Thailand also noted with appreciation that the Government would carry out a comprehensive review of the implementation of measures and programmes to provide assistance to landmine victims. Thailand was pleased to note that most of the recommendations relating to such important matters as the rights of women, children, persons with disabilities, vulnerable and marginalized groups enjoyed the support of the Republic of Korea.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

572. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of the Republic of Korea, 6 other stakeholders made statements.

573. The National Human Rights Commission of Korea (NHRCK) welcomed the Republic of Koreas acceptance of 42 recommendations out of a total of 70. Regarding the remaining recommendations not yet accepted, NHRCK urged the Government to sustain its interest in ultimately addressing those pending issues and in continuously monitoring progress. According to NHRCK, sometimes the administration could not fully address human rights violations without social consensus and bipartisan agreement in the National Assembly. NHRCK pointed to the diversity of emerging human rights issues and the greater roles and more influence exerted by non-governmental organizations. NHRCK stated that human rights issues making the headlines did not always coincide with the publics demands of issues to be urgently addressed. Since human rights reports submitted by Governments or civil society did not always paint a full picture of the countrys human rights situation, NHRCK would fulfil its role in presenting its independent opinion in an objective and unbiased manner.

574. Amnesty International (AI) noted that similar recommendations relating to addressing discrimination against migrant workers and guaranteeing full enjoyment of the rights of migrant workers were accepted by the Republic of Korea in 2008. AI regretted their poor implementation and urged the Government to take concrete measures to respect, protect and promote the rights of all migrant workers, both documented and undocumented, and to take steps to eliminate restrictions on their labour mobility. AI expressed its disappointment that a number of key recommendations were rejected, including for ratification of OP2-ICCPR and establishing a moratorium on executions as a step towards the full abolition of the death penalty and in providing genuine alternatives to military service for conscientious objectors. AI deplored the rejection of recommendations to abolish or amend the National Security Law in line with international standards. According to AI, vaguely worded clauses in the Law were misused to target individuals and groups perceived to oppose government policy. AI believed that the Governments failure to accept those recommendations indicated a worrying lack of commitment to guaranteeing the right to freedom of expression.

575. Asian Forum for Human Rights and Development (Forum Asia) made a statement in association with Peoples Solidarity for Participatory Democracy (PSPD) expressing appreciation for the Republic of Koreas timely submission of its position on recommendations made. They regretted that several recommendations repeated from the first cycle continued not to enjoy, such as the ratification of ICRMW. They were disappointed at the Governments position on amending the National Security Act. In their view, the number of people prosecuted under that Act exceeded the number of convictions, indicating its arbitrary application and the Act had also been invoked to forcibly shut down an increasing number of websites and blogs. They highlighted the Governments rejection of recommendations to ratify core ILO Conventions, despite pledges to that end when elected to the Human Rights Council in 2006 and 2008. They were also disturbed by the increasing trend of judicial harassment against peaceful protesters under the charge of obstruction of justice for police officers. The use of force by private security personnel against peaceful protesters was also alarming. They remained appalled that the Government had not effectively addressed this situation on the ground, allegedly rendering it complicit in the violence and coercion. They referred to violent disruptions by police and private security of peaceful protests in Gangjeong village since 2007 and appealed to the Special Rapporteur on human rights defenders to address such acts during her upcoming visit in May. They also called on the Government to also exert all efforts to fully realise the right of local communities to their free, prior and informed consent. Finally, they urged the Government to conduct genuine and transparent consultations with civil society organizations at all stages of the UPR process and to create an oversight mechanism on the status of implementation of UN human rights systems recommendations, involving all relevant institutions and agencies as well as the National Assembly.

576. Save the Children International welcomed the Governments acceptance of most of the childrens rights related UPR recommendations. They drew attention to the recommendation by nine States that every child should be registered without discrimination regardless of the status and nationality of his or her parents and to the Governments response that the current system was already fulfilling those rights. According to Save the Children Internationals research on refugee children in the Republic of Korea 19 out of 50 children in the sample were stateless. They proposed the adoption of an automatic birth registration at the hospital and the protection of single mothers privacy through modification of the Registration System of Family Relationships. While noting the Governments acceptance of recommendations on the prohibition of corporal punishment, they referred to a provision of the Enforcement Decree of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, which allegedly left the possibility for humiliating and disciplinary punishment to be inflicted and called for the Government to revise the law to prohibit those forms of punishment as soon as possible.

577. CIVICUS - World Alliance for Citizen Participation welcomed the launching of the second National Plan of Action for the Protection and Promotion of Human Rights (2012-2016). CIVICUS expressed its concern at the shrinking space for freedoms of expression, association, assembly and the right to peaceful protest. CIVICUS drew attention to the issue of the alleged silencing of dissenting voices under the National Security Act (NSA) and that the internet remained a highly restricted space. According to CIVICUS, by October 2012 the police had deleted 67,300 web sites that they believed threatened national security, and several restrictions had been placed on freedom of peaceful assembly through application of the Assembly and Demonstration Act as well as the Criminal Act. CIVICUS urged the Government to repeal or suitably amend the NSA, to bring to justice law enforcement carrying out wrongful arrests and to take further action to remove limitations on internet content so as to ensure freedom of expression, including opinions which are different from the positions of the Government.

578. International Fellowship of Reconciliation (IFOR) reported that seven States made recommendations regarding non-recognition of conscientious objection to military service and the imprisonment of conscientious objectors. They were combined in recommendation 53, which was listed as not enjoying the support of the Republic of Korea, although the Government did undertake to examine the issue. IFOR stated that the Republic of Korea continued to imprison almost 500 young men each year for refusing military service on the grounds of conscience, more than any other State in the world. According to IFOR, other States faced with a difficult security situation and the lack of public consensus had fully respected the right of conscientious objection to military service. IFOR called upon the Republic of Korea: to delay no longer in providing for conscientious objection to military service in legislation conforming to international standards; to take a positive role in the formation of a popular consensus on that issue; and to immediately cease imprisoning those who refused military service on grounds of conscience, providing them instead with the opportunity to opt for a civilian alternative service when it became available.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

579. The delegation thanked all speakers for their constructive comments, which would serve as valuable sources for the Government to further strengthen its already firm commitment to achieving higher standards of human rights.

580. However, it disagreed with arguments that the National Security Law was arbitrarily applied. The Law was necessary for the countrys existence and security due to the unique security circumstances facing the country. It was emphasized that the Act was strictly interpreted and applied in compliance with the guidelines for interpretation of the Act presented in the rulings of the Constitutional Court and the Supreme Court. The Act was limited in its application only to cases where there was a clear threat of actual harm to the existence and security of the State or the fundamental democratic order. This was interpreted and applied so that freedom of expression, association and assembly were guaranteed to the fullest extent possible.

581. The Republic of Korea remained firmly supportive of the UPR and to the promotion of the UPR mechanism and renewed its gratitude to the Troika – Hungary, Indonesia and Djibouti - and the Secretariat for their hard work in the process.

Switzerland

582. The review of Switzerland was held on 29 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Switzerland in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/CHE/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/CHE/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/CHE/3).

583. At its 36th meeting, on 14 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Switzerland (see section C below).

584. The outcome of the review of Switzerland comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/11), the views of Switzerland concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group (see also A/HRC/22/11/Add.1).

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

585. The Swiss delegation highlighted the close cooperation between the Federal Department of Foreign Affairs, the Federal Department of Justice and Police and all Cantons during the UPR exercise and thanked the civil societys contribution. Switzerland acknowledged the UPR as a mechanism to strengthen the human rights protection.

586. Switzerland thanked the 81 States which intervened in the interactive dialogue in October 2012. At that time, 69 States addressed 140 recommendations, 50 of which were accepted and 4 rejected. The remaining 86 recommendations were analysed through a participative and inclusive process among the Cantons, the Federal authorities and NGOs, resulting in the Federal Council decision to accept 49 recommendations and to reject 37.

587. The decision to accept or reject recommendations was made taking into account the implementing measures already in force, Switzerlands capacity for such implementation and whether the accepted recommendations could be implemented before its next UPR. By accepting recommendations, Switzerland committed to continue its efforts and measures already in place. Switzerland clarified that recommendations were not accepted where the Government or the Parliament had not yet taken any decision or issued any clear political willingness to adopt the recommended measures.

588. Switzerland was currently discussing about ICCPR-OP1 ratification, on the basis of a study prepared by the Swiss Centre of Expertise on Human Rights, but no political decision had been taken yet.

589. Switzerland informed that its current sectorial approach to fight against discrimination was more effective than a general law against discrimination. Switzerland adopted targeted measures to better protect against discrimination, highlighting the following laws; a) the Gender Equality Act contained special measures against women discrimination in the labour market; b) the Federal Registered Partnerships Act offered homosexual couples, in many respects, the rights of married couples and the Parliament was discussing a modification to enable a person in a registered partnership to adopt its partners child; and c) the Federal Act on the Elimination of Discrimination against People with Disabilities contained accessibility measures to buildings, public transportation and services.

590. Switzerland rejected the recommendation to establish an independent complaints mechanism on police violence in each Canton because, due to the separation of powers, complaints to an independent judicial authority were already possible in every Canton. The Swiss Centre of Expertise on Human Rights was preparing a study of the Cantons complaints mechanisms, which will serve as a basis to consider their advantages and disadvantages and to exchange best practices.

591. Switzerland rejected to include the definition of torture in the Criminal Code because all acts which constituted torture were already criminalized in such Code and were subjected to appropriate penalties. The Federal Constitution guaranteed the absolute prohibition of torture.

592. The separation of minors and adults in temporary custody was already guaranteed by the Swiss law. The effective implementation of such guarantee depended on the availability of appropriate structures within the Cantons. Therefore, a timeframe of 10 years has been granted to the Cantons to set up the necessary measures. As the deadline to implement the recommendation will expire at the end of 2016, same period of its third UPR, Switzerland rejected this recommendation.

593. Switzerland already adopted several measures to fight against human trafficking. Switzerland has an exhaustive legal framework such as the Criminal Code, which prosecutes and punishes those responsible; the Federal Law on the Aid of Victims of Violations, which provides support to victims; and the Federal Act on Foreign Nationals which contains specific provisions on victims stays. The above system has enabled Switzerland to ratify the Convention of the Council of Europe on action against trafficking in human beings.

594. The National Action Plan to Fight Human Trafficking, adopted in 2012 by the Federal Council, foresees measures regarding prevention, criminal prosecution, victims protection and cooperation with those states of transit and origin of victims, which have been integrated into a comprehensive strategy. Financial contribution has also been granted to NGOs that provide specialized assistance to victims.

595. In 2009 the Federal Council set up the Centre of Expertise on Human Rights for a pilot period of 5 years, confirming Switzerlands voluntary commitment, assumed in 2008, to establish a national human rights institution. The pilot project will provide elements for a final political decision in that regard. By accepting the recommendation, Switzerland is not anticipating the outcome of the pilot study nor the final Government decision. Switzerland will inform the Human Rights Council accordingly.

596. About a recommendation made by Namibia, not reflected in the Working Group Report, Switzerland clarified that in the framework of the mandatory medical insurance, insurances were obligated to set identical rates for men and women, so the Swiss health care system was equitable regarding the insurances rates of women and men.

597. Finally, it was noted that, even if Switzerland enjoyed a favourable human rights situation, the human rights promotion was a permanent task. The second UPR enabled Switzerland to intensify the human rights debate at all political levels. The Swiss federalism, the direct democracy and the sectorial approach provided new developments taking into account the Confederation, Cantons and Communes as well as the civil society.

598. An inter-departmental group, composed by representatives of the Government and the Cantons was created to discuss the recommendations and related human rights issues. Further discussions have been carried out with the Swiss NGO-Coalition and the Centre of Expertise on Human Rights. The reinforced relations between the Government, the Cantons, the civil society and the citizens will enable the effective implementation of accepted recommendations.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

599. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Switzerland, 14 delegations made statements.

600. Romania appreciated Switzerlands commitment to further improving the promotion and respect of human rights. It trusted that Switzerlands support to the majority of recommendations received would contribute to the achievement of such goal. It indicated that Romania would continue to cooperate with the Swiss authorities in order to support their efforts in the field of human rights.

601. Togo thanked Switzerland for its presentation and update. It was pleased with the high level of human rights protection system and encouraged Switzerland to accelerate its policy on integration and combating discrimination in all cantons.

602. Viet Nam appreciated the concrete initiatives and measures taken to implement the accepted recommendations. It noted that there was remaining room for further improvements, especially in the areas of fighting racial discrimination, social integration for migrants as well as a holistic plan for gender equality. It stressed that the illustrative history of the Swiss Confederation was an example of effective international cooperation.

603. Algeria appreciated the acceptance of its recommendation to intensify efforts in fighting racism, discrimination, intolerance and xenophobia. It recalled its statement at the presentation of Switzerlands report that Switzerland had come a long way in its quest for promoting and protecting the rights of its citizens. However, it regretted that Switzerland did not accept the recommendation to ratify ICRMW.

604. Botswana applauded progress made towards the protection and promotion of human rights since the first UPR cycle. It commended Switzerland for the ratification of OP-CEDAW and OP-CAT. It welcomed the establishment of the Swiss Centre for Human Rights and noted with satisfaction efforts made towards ratifying other international instruments.

605. Burkina Faso renewed its congratulations to Switzerland for completing the second review and took note of initiatives taken in order to implement accepted recommendations. It praised Switzerlands cooperation with the Human Rights Council mechanisms. It encouraged Switzerland to continue its dynamics in protecting and promoting human rights.

606. Cte dIvoire thanked Switzerland for having accepted recommendations received. It noted with satisfaction Switzerlands engagement regarding important issues for the Human Rights Council, such as the transitional justice and the swift adoption of resolutions on serious situations of open conflict. It commended Swiss initiatives in the area of humanitarian action.

607. Cuba highlighted progress made in the areas of gender, violence against women, rights of the child and of persons with disabilities, yet stressed that challenges still remained regarding racism, racial discrimination and xenophobia. Noting that the 0.7 per cent of GDP target for ODA had not been met, it called upon Switzerland to increase its contribution. It appreciated that Switzerland supported Cubas recommendations to prevent racism, enhance equal opportunity and consider withdrawing the reservation to article 4 of ICERD.

608. Ecuador appreciated the support to a high number of recommendations, including Ecuadors ones. It regretted the rejection of several recommendations to ratify ICRMW and urged Switzerland to reconsider its position. It also regretted that Switzerland had rejected recommendations to adopt a legislation to prohibit incitement to racism, discrimination, intolerance, xenophobia and hatred speech.

609. Gabon commended Switzerlands collaboration with international procedures and mechanisms for the protection and promotion of human rights. It acknowledged efforts in combating racism, xenophobia and all relevant forms of discrimination and intolerance, as well as efforts in fighting discrimination against women with a view to reducing inequality between men and women.

610. The Lao Peoples Democratic Republic commended Switzerlands achievements and commitments in upholding and promoting human rights and humanitarian principles. It noted the acceptance of a great number of recommendations as well as steps already taken to implement these. It acknowledged Switzerlands efforts in adopting a wide range of legislative measures, policies and programmes to strengthen gender equality and womens rights, and in combatting violence against women and trafficking in persons.

611. Namibia regretted the omission, in the outcome report, of one of its recommendations made at the review of Switzerland, which referred to the healthcare system that charged higher fees to women based on their gender. It requested to include such recommendation in the list of recommendations. Hence, it recommended Switzerland to ensure equal fees for insurance premiums for women and men in public and private health care systems.

612. The Philippines noted that despite the rejection to the recommendations to consider ratifying ICRMW, it appreciated Switzerlands commitment to ensure the protection of refugees, migrants and their family members. While welcoming voluntary commitments to address the situation of migrants and travellers, it hoped that in the future Switzerland would join current Member States of ICRMW. It was pleased with the acceptance of its recommendation to consider ratifying ILO Convention No. 189.

613. The Republic of Moldova welcomed Switzerlands efforts in improving the protection and promotion of human rights, including the establishment of the Swiss Centre for Human Rights. It appreciated the adoption of laws, policies and programmes with a view to strengthening gender equality, as well as progress made in combating domestic violence. It further appreciated the acceptance of its two recommendations.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

614. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Switzerland, eight stakeholders made statements.

615. European Region of the International Lesbian and Gay Federation, on behalf of five national LGBT organizations, regretted the rejection of all recommendations regarding discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, underscoring that LGBT persons were victims of numerous forms of discrimination.
