It regretted the lack of legal protection of LGBT persons in the Registered Partnership Act and the Labour Act. It called upon Switzerland to adopt a general law on all forms of discrimination.

616. World Evangelical Alliance (WEA) noted the acceptance of 12 recommendations on combating human trafficking. It called upon Switzerland to: undertake an independent study to assess the magnitude of this scourge; punish the perpetrators with appropriate sentences; involve all Cantons in the identification and protection of victims; and intensify international cooperation by engaging all concerned stakeholders, including civil society. It would continue to dialogue and cooperate with Switzerland in the implementation of accepted recommendations.

617. Amnesty International acknowledged the satisfactory consultation with civil society and Cantons prior to the review. It welcomed the support to recommendations on establishing a NHRI and developing an action programme to combat racial discrimination, yet noted the rejection of the recommendation to ratify OP-ICESCR. While regretting the rejection of recommendations on combating discrimination, establishing an independent complaint mechanism for cases of police violence, criminalizing torture, and detaining minors separately from adults, it urged Switzerland to reconsider its position.

618. Verein Sdwind Entwicklungspolitik regretted the rejection of the recommendation to ratify the 1961 Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness. It featured a case of an individual who had been unsuccessfully seeking asylum in various European countries, including Switzerland. It further regretted that Switzerland also rejected the recommendation to provide suitable accommodation for all asylum seekers.

619. Action Canada for Population and Development, on behalf of Sexual Rights Initiative and Sexual Health Switzerland, was concerned at the rejection of recommendation 123.76 as well as to the Australias recommendation to establish anti-discrimination Ombudsmen in all Cantons. It urged Switzerland to remedy the barriers faced by vulnerable groups to accessing reproductive health services and to develop a national strategy to ensure access for children and adolescents to sexual education. It noted that Switzerland did not respond to Finlands advanced question on sexual rights of persons with disabilities.

620. Istituto Internazionale Maria Ausiliatrice (IIMA) and International Volunteerism Organisation for Women, Education, Development (VIDES) regretted the rejection of recommendation 122.46 to ensure the best possible level of education to children from disadvantaged background and foreign origin. It called upon Switzerland to: implement recommendations 122.46; implement recommendation 123.82 through public programmes to prevent youth suicide and drug use; recognize secondary education to guarantee equal opportunity for every child; and guarantee childrens right to health by making health insurance more affordable for low-income residents.

621. Press Emblem Campaign (PEC) noted that the obligation to protect journalists in conflict zones under the Geneva Conventions had repeatedly not been observed in recent years. It called upon Switzerland, before submitting its next periodic report to the Council, to consult the High Contracting Parties in order to identify means to strengthen the protection of journalists and media workers in conflict zones through concrete and effective mechanisms complementing the general provisions of the Geneva Conventions.

622. Association of World Citizens regretted the low rate of naturalization in Switzerland. It deplored that entry visas and work permits might be revoked at any time, including in cases where the person lived and worked in Switzerland for 25 years, since the integration was evaluated on the sole basis of dependence to social aid. It welcomed the harmonization of cantonal practices and called upon Switzerland to take into account other elements, such as the personal situation and the rights of the child.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

623. Switzerland thanked all States and civil society organizations for the cooperation provided during its second UPR, which highly contributed to the countrys reflections on human rights. Switzerland will take into account the delegations remarks in its efforts to implement the accepted recommendations.

 

Pakistan

624. The review of Pakistan was held on 30 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Pakistan in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/PAK/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/PAK/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/PAK/3).

625. At its 37th meeting, on 14 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Pakistan (see section C below).

626. The outcome of the review of Pakistan comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/12), the views of Pakistan concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group (see also A/HRC/22/12/Add.1).

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

627. The Ambassador of Pakistan expressed deep appreciation to those who participated in the interactive dialogue, as well as the members of the Troika and the Secretariat, for their support in the conduct of its UPR in October 2012.

628. The delegation informed that Pakistan participated in the second cycle of the Universal Periodic Review in a constructive and inclusive manner as the interactive dialogue provided them with an opportunity to highlight significant strides made by Pakistan for the protection and promotion of human rights and take stock of the challenges that they face in the full realization of the human rights of its citizens.

629. The delegation stated that Pakistan received 166 recommendations during the review and rejected one recommendation during the Working Group session. They informed that following the adoption of the UPR report on Pakistan by the Working Group on 2 November 2012, the 165 recommendations were sent to all concerned departments for consideration and response.

630. The delegation informed the Council that out of the 165 recommendations, 126 recommendations enjoyed the support of Pakistan. Out of these 126 recommendations, 73 recommendations have either already been implemented or are in the process of implementation while 34 recommendations have been noted. These recommendations have not been rejected as such, but the due process of consultations on them has not been completed on time and they will continue the deliberations on these recommendations.

631. The delegation illustrated that seven recommendations were not accepted as they pertain to the repeal of blasphemy laws and the abolition of the death penalty. While the Government has accepted and is was already implementing recommendations that call on it to take measures to prevent the misuse of blasphemy laws, as there is was no national consensus on the repeal of these laws. As regards, the abolition of the death penalty, the delegation informed that this is was a matter for the Parliament to decide. The executive could only impose an unofficial moratorium on executions which was already in place.

632. The delegation clarified that a number of recommendations were made regarding the ratification of international human rights instruments and clarified that Pakistan is was a party to 7 core human rights instruments. At present, the government was focusing on the implementation of these Conventions. Its accession to new international instruments is examined under a constant and gradual process in which the implications of ratification are were considered in terms of consistency and adaptation of national law and practice, and also in terms of the financial implications of the effective implementation of the instruments concerned.

633. On the recommendations made for the promotion and protection of rights of women the delegation informed the Council that on 12th February 2013, Pakistan presented its Fourth Periodic Report to CEDAW and the experts acknowledged the resolve of the government to advance womens rights and appreciated the steps taken so far in this regard.

634. The delegation also stated that a number of recommendations were made to continue its national efforts to design and implement policies and programmes aimed at improving the socio-economic conditions of its people. The delegation noted with appreciation that the international community valued the commitment of the Government to poverty alleviation and improving the living standards of its citizens.

635. The delegation recognized the fact that no country could embark upon the path to prosperity without ensuring universal education to its future generation. Therefore, Pakistan enacted the Free and Compulsory Education Bill 2012 in December last year to provide free and compulsory education to all children.

636. The delegation explained in regard to the recommendations made for the promotion and protection of the rights of minorities, which all minorities were equal citizens and enjoy equal rights and protection. The extremist ideology espoused by a misguided fringe minority could not undermine rights given to minorities by Islam and the constitution of Pakistan. A National Interfaith and Inter-Cultural Conference was organized with the view to promote harmony amongst followers of different faiths. The delegation acknowledged the need that more to be done for the welfare of minorities in Pakistan, but it is was important to underscore that there was no organized official intolerance toward religious minorities in Pakistan. Most cases of excess against members of the minority communities were on account of personal animosities or an endeavour by a few extremist elements to impose their own agenda on both majority and minority communities.

637. The delegation reiterated that the people of Pakistan were committed to democratic ideals. On 15 March, a democratically elected Government would complete its five year term. The democratic government, in its five years tenure, has made significant strides for the promotion of democracy and human rights in the country by passing landmark legislation for strengthening democracy, promoting rule of law and protecting human rights.

638. The delegation stressed that efforts of the Government to protect and promote human rights were for the sake of their people and not for the international community or the civil society.

639. The delegation acknowledged the challenges they have faced in the realm of human rights with a view to dealing with them in a comprehensive manner and said that the Government remained committed to vigorously protecting and promoting the human rights of its people as well as fulfilling all its international human rights obligations.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

640. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Pakistan, 15 delegations made statements. The statements of the delegations that were unable to deliver them owing to time constraints[54] are posted on the extranet of the Human Rights Council, if available.

641. Indonesia noted the consistent and genuine commitment for human rights and the commitment in implementing the 126 accepted recommendations. It welcomed the Governments various legal, institutional and administrative initiatives on the advancement of women. It noted that the acceptance of the relevant UPR recommendations during the second cycle will definitely further progress and efforts to address existing challenges on the advancement of women in Pakistan.

642. The Islamic Republic of Iran commended the active participation in the UPR process and welcomed the constructive engagement with the Council by accepting many recommendations made to it. The Islamic Republic of Iran also commended Pakistans efforts to ensure economic and social rights of its people including reduction of poverty and improvement of education by making available financial and human resources for literacy programs.

643. Malaysia commended Pakistan for its engagement in the UPR process and its willingness to accept the larger number of recommendations including its own recommendations. They recognised that Pakistan ratified almost all international human rights instruments as well as improvements in the area of education, health, housing, social welfare and the empowerment of women, among others. Malaysia noted the challenges that remained on a number of human rights issues and encouraged Pakistan to continue strengthening its efforts at ensuring the enjoyment of all human rights by its citizens.

644. Morocco thanked Pakistan for accepting most of the recommendations addressed to it during the UPR which demonstrated commitment to Human rights through the ratification of the main human rights instruments and its efforts to bring in line its national legislations with international obligations. Morocco appreciated the effort made for certain categories of population such as women and the disabled. They welcomed the decision of the government to create a National Commission on the Status of Women and ratification of the Convention on the rights of disabled person. They welcomed the effort of National Institution of Human rights for its initiative to draft a national plan of action on human rights.

645. Myanmar expressed its appreciation for the constructive and active participation in the second cycle of the UPR process. It was pleased to note that Pakistan has accepted a great number of recommendations made by Member States including Myanmar.

646. The Philippines noted Pakistan continued support to the UPR process which affirms that this mechanism is an effective State led voluntary process and inclusive mechanism that can effect positive changes to legislation, policies and programs in order to further protect and advance human rights. It encouraged Pakistan to continue its transparent and constructive engagement with the HRC. It welcomed Pakistans adherence to the protection of human rights not only of its people but also of the 3 million refugees it is hosting, despite severe economic and human resources constraints.

647. Qatar valued the acceptance of the two recommendations it made during the interactive dialogue, in addition to Pakistan commitment to examine another 33 recommendations. This reflects the commitment and the real will of Pakistan in dealing positively and constructively with the HRC and the UN Mechanisms. Qatar highly valued the achievements and the continuous efforts in promoting and protecting human rights, the fundamental freedoms, justice and rule of law at the legislative and executive levels in spite of all the challenges facing Pakistan. They appreciated the human rights role Pakistan plays at the HRC in bridging views as the coordinator of the OIC.

648. The Russian Federation stated that the review of Pakistan in the second cycle demonstrated that Pakistan took all possible measures to improve the national human rights mechanisms and actively involve civil society in developing various political and economic initiatives. The Russian Federation noted with appreciation that Pakistan accepted the majority of recommendations put forward during the review, which has demonstrated the readiness of the authorities to strengthen and improve its capacity in promoting and protecting human rights.

649. Saudi Arabia acknowledged Pakistans continuing in the same positive spirit of cooperation with all UN Mechanisms and Procedures, and its readiness to cooperate and dialogue on human rights issues; through the ratifications of treaties; the efforts made to develop laws and institutions related to human rights and the amendments made to the Constitution since 2010. They appreciated the regional role Pakistan played to enhance human rights that resulted in the establishment of the Human Rights Committee at the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation in 2011 and the Forum of South Asia to end violence against children.

650. Sri Lanka congratulated Pakistan for accepting a majority of the recommendations made during the review and understood that some of these recommendations are already in the process of implementation. Sri Lanka commended Pakistan for the significant strides made in the promotion and protection of human rights in the last four years, despite challenges faced on different fronts. It noted the efforts at eradicating terrorism, and stressed that it stands by Pakistan in its endeavour to secure peace and security for its people.

651. The Sudan noted that to achieve the goal of the UPR, States record of human rights cannot be evaluated in isolation of a study to the situation on the ground within its context and based on factual information. The Sudan therefore commended Pakistan for its efforts in spite of all the challenges during (2008-2012) by accomplishing many legislative steps, particularly the six laws for the promotion of womens rights and the law that established the national Human Rights Institution in accordance with Paris Principles.

652. Thailand welcomed the acceptance of both recommendations it made, on which both countries share common concern and interests. It recognised that Pakistan had given importance to guaranteeing the rights of religious minorities and ensures free practice of faith and religion to live in peace and harmony. It appreciated the committed efforts to ensure access to education and give priority to the right to education for its population as a means to improve socio-economic development in the country.

653. United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Island (UK) welcomed the clear commitment to the UPR process and offered its practical support in implementing the recommendations. The UK was reminded of the challenges Pakistan faces by the tragic recent attacks on Shia Muslims and this weekends anti-Christian riots. The UK provided sympathy and its support in addressing terrorism and extremism. It encouraged the authorities to do all they can to protect minority communities. The UK supported Pakistans efforts to ensure that the elections are credible and acceptable to its people as a vital step on the path to a strong and stable democracy.

654. United Arab Emirates welcomed the efforts in establishing a culture of human rights and fundamental freedoms through measures at all levels in different aspects that will guarantee the dignity of individuals and achieve equality and the principle of equal opportunities among people. They commended the commitment of Pakistan in economic, social and cultural rights to achieve sustainable development and social justice. They also commended the political will to implement all the accepted recommendations and to continue its cooperation with the international community and the Council to enhance human rights.

655. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela appreciated the commitment in the promotion and protection of human rights, by providing an open cooperation with the mechanism of the UPR. They commended the efforts in the implementation of the recommendations received, with the ratification of important international human rights treaties and the adoption of legal and administrative initiatives in favour of womens rights, giving priority to their political and economic empowerment. They commended the progress made in the field of the rights of the child, health, education and in the fight against poverty and social exclusion, despite the economic challenges and natural disasters.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

656. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Pakistan, 10 other stakeholders made statements. The statements of the stakeholders that were unable to deliver them owing to time constraints[55] are posted on the extranet of the Human Rights Council, if available.

657. Human Rights Watch appreciated the acceptance of recommendations on religious hatred, prevent violence against religious minorities. They noted the number of killings that took place in 2012 and 2013 in may provinces. They indicated that the government was unable or unwilling to break the links of Pakistans military and intelligence agencies with extremist groups, as law enforcement officials also turned a blind eye to attacks or to hold extremist groups accountable particularly the perception of attacks against Shias. They regretted the rejection of the recommendations to revise discriminatory blasphemy laws, and noted the hundreds of Christians who had to flee their homes in Lahore on 9 March 2013.

658. International Federation for Human Rights and the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan urged Pakistan to step up efforts to protect religious minorities from physical attacks, forced conversion and socio-economic discrimination, especially in light of the recent outburst of violence against Shia communities and to urgently amend discriminatory laws which contribute to the persecution of minorities. They were concerned by the insecurity of human rights defenders and journalists investigating human rights violations. They noted that the number of death sentences has remained high and there were 7,046 death row inmates in jails by the end of February and called for an official moratorium.

659. Amnesty International (AI) encouraged the government to provide regularly updates to civil society on the implementation of the recommendations. AI noted that little progress was made in determining the fate of thousands of people subjected to enforced disappearances. They urged Pakistan to criminalise enforced disappearances; ratify CED and investigate and prosecute those responsible for those acts. It urged taking measures to address the climate of vilification on the bases of religion and to bring to justice those who commit religiously-motivated acts of violence, and to consider repealing blasphemy laws. It urged developing a national policy for the protection of human rights defenders and to prosecute perpetrators.

660. Asian Forum for Human Rights and Development noted the initial measures towards implementing some recommendations, however much more is required for their meaningful impacts, such as a timeline for the domestication of ratified treaties. They urged taking urgent steps, particularly a legislation that bans child labour. They were concerned that NCHR legislation falls short of international standards. They called for addressing violations under blasphemy laws and the digital surveillance tools used to curtail freedom of expression. They noted the attacks against human rights defenders, aid workers and journalists and called for adopting comprehensive protection legislation as well as establishing an adequate protection mechanism.

661. United Nations Watch noted that Pakistan has a particular responsibility to uphold the highest standards in the promotion and protection of human rights. UN Watch questioned why they continue to hear of extrajudicial killings and enforced disappearances. It also asked about attacks against Christians, Shias, Ahmadis and other minorities. It referred to the last attack killing 45 and wounding 146 of Shiites in Karachi. They raised issues of women rights and the 96 attacks on schools in 2012 making Pakistan among the most dangerous places in the world to go to school today. UN Watch called for repealing blasphemy laws immediately.

662. World Environment and Resources Council hoped that the next elected government would have the courage to tackle many of the problems that troubled the people of Pakistan and have prevented them from enjoying a life of freedom and prosperity. They quoted a Pakistani human rights activist words on the democratic process and the four years of the democratic rule.

663. International Commission of Jurists expressed regret over the recent events reversing a de facto moratorium on the imposition of death penalty as the execution on 15 November ended the unofficial moratorium since 2008, which they considered a major step back for human rights. They reported that more than 7,000 persons are in the death row, as capital punishment is prescribed for 27 different offences many of them do not meet the threshold of most serious crimes, as stipulated by Article 6 of the ICCPR. They urged accepting the recommendation to adopt an official moratorium with a view to abolish death penalty in law and accede to the 2nd OP-ICCPR as well as to ratify CED and resolve all cases of enforced disappearances.

664. Action Canada for Population and Development welcomed the support for the recommendation on early and forced marriage with a view to eliminating it, to end rape and sexual exploitation and forced conversion of scheduled caste girls and urged for immediate steps in this regard. They noted that Pakistan is one of the highest infant mortality and under five mortality rate in South Asia, as it is also linked to early and forced marriages. They noted the inconsistency of the age of marriage for girls and boys and its impact on education, development. They urged Pakistan to end violations against women and raise marriage age for girls to 18 and enforce the law.

665. Fondazione Marista per la Solidariet Internazionale ONLUS, speaking also on behalf of Franciscans International, Save the Children International and VIVAT International, noted the use of corporal punishment in schools and the absence of effective legislations to reduce the number of children working on the streets or in the factories contrary to the Constitution on the age of employment and hazardous work. They reported that children died as a result of abuse particularly domestic workers. They were concerned of the involvement of children in armed conflict. Women continue to face challenges despite efforts and recommended the ratification of OP-CEDAW especially to protect women from religious and minority groups.

666. Jubilee Campaign was concerned regarding the economic, political and social marginalisation of minorities. They considered the education curriculum and teaching as one of the root causes of the increasing prejudice in society, and urged ensuring that children's textbooks are non-discriminatory and promote freedom of religion or belief. Pakistans blasphemy laws and anti-Ahmadiyya provisions lack defined terms and false accusations can be easily registered. They noted that perpetrators are rarely brought to justice, and hate speech is a standard precursor to religiously-motivated violence, but is rarely punished, despite the existence of legislation. They urged for greater efforts to protect religious minorities, to ensure rule of law, and justice for those who suffer intimidation and violence.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

667. The delegation thanked the President of the Human Rights Council for his ruling cautioning the speakers not to use language that is inconsistent with decorum of the Council during their interventions.

668. The delegation stressed that the actions of extremists and radical elements in their society should not be confused with the policies of the government of Pakistan. There was no officially sanctioned policy of discrimination on the bases of religion or any other bases against the people of Pakistan. They expressed deep regret over the fact that some members of minority communities were targeted by extremist elements. The delegation said that these acts were meant to create disunity within their country by groups who were pursuing an extremist and radical agenda and such acts although numerous have remained localized.

669. On the attack on the Christian community in Lahore, the delegation deplored the incident and shared with the Council the steps taken by the government, judiciary and civil society in the aftermath of the incident.

670. On the cases of human rights defenders and journalists who have been targeted, the delegation clarified that they were targets of people who are involved in acts of terrorism against the State and the people of Pakistan. In terms of threats faced by Pakistan, the delegation mentioned that the situation in Pakistan should be analysed and understood in terms of complex security situation in its neighbourhood.

671. Finally, the delegation thanked the President of the Council and the Members that participated in the debate and the Secretariat who helped in making this session possible and for the adoption of the UPR Report.

Zambia

672. The review of Zambia was held on 30 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Zambia in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/ZAM/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/ZAM/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/ZAM/3).

673. At its 37th meeting, on 14 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Zambia (see section C below).

674. The outcome of the review of Zambia comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/13), the views of Zambia concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group (see also A/HRC/22/13/Add.1).

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

675. The delegation, headed by Mr. Musa Mwenye, Solicitor General and State Council of Zambia, expressed Zambias delight in participating in its second universal periodic review. This process has not only served to highlight the tremendous progress Zambia has made since its first review in 2008, but has also helped the Government to reflect on the short comings in certain areas.

676. The delegation stated that Zambia was determined to continue to improve its human rights protection and also expressed Zambias gratitude to all the countries that made recommendations. The delegation reiterated Zambias commitment to the advancement of democracy and the observance of human rights.

677. The delegation recalled that Zambia received 125 recommendations, 70 of which were immediately accepted and 1 rejected. The remaining 54 recommendations were deferred for further consultations. The delegation stated that those consultations have since been held at the highest level and with different stakeholders, including civil society, and it was ultimately decided to reject 33 of the aforementioned 54 recommendations.

678. The delegation stated that Zambia was currently undergoing a constitutional review process which was solely people-driven with the Government playing a strictly facilitative role. Although the Government agreed with the recommendations on womens rights, childrens rights and the need to reform the constitution to remove most discriminatory clauses, it was compelled to reject all recommendations that would have the effect of pre-empting the outcome of the current constitution making process. This has been done to ensure that the Constitution is truly a result of the will of the people without any form of prompting from the Government.

679. The delegation stated that the recommendation on extending an invitation to special mandate holders has been rejected because Zambia has already extended an open invitation to all special mandate holders, and therefore sees no added value in extending further special invitations. Special Mandate Holders were urged to take advantage of this open invitation.

680. As regards the recommendation on criminalizing marital rape, the delegation stated that Zambia was not aware that marital rape was a problem. However, the Government expressed its willingness to consult widely on the effect of enacting a law criminalizing marital rape with particular emphasis on the possible adverse repercussions on the traditional cohesion of the family. The delegation added that Zambia has enacted comprehensive Anti-Gender based violence legislation that enhances the rights of women with regards to gender based violence of all forms. The Government welcomed constructive debate on this issue.

681. The delegation stated that Zambia rejected the recommendation on freedom of expression because of the belief that while the freedom of expression should be respected and enhanced, it must not be exercised in contravention of those constitutional provisions which maintain the country as a unitary state.

682. The delegation expressed the assurance that Zambia took the recommendations which it has accepted seriously and will accordingly begin the process of consultation with a view to implementing them. The Government has committed itself to working with all stakeholders who have a genuine interest in the protection of human rights.

683. Finally, the delegation stated that it was possible that many of the recommendations which touched on the process of constitutional reform and the content of the Zambian Constitution will be implemented once the constitutional making process is completed. The delegation anticipated that the final draft constitution will be ready by June 2013, after which it will be subjected to the approval by the people of Zambia through the institutions and processes available for such approval.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

684. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Zambia, 11 delegations made statements. The statements of the delegations that were unable to deliver them owing to time constraints[56] are posted on the extranet of the Human Rights Council, if available.

685. Burkina Faso encouraged Zambia to continue in its momentum of implementing recommendations, particularly those relating to the ratification of relevant human rights treaties, the fight against racism and the trafficking of persons. It noted Zambias efforts to improve its human rights situation and called for a continuation of these efforts. Burkina Faso expressed the hope that the ongoing constitutional reform process will help to promote human rights.

686. Cuba noted that despite Zambias material inadequacies it endeavoured to prioritise the protection of human rights. It congratulated Zambia on its efforts to attain the Millennium Development Goals. Zambia has focused its attention on broadening access to secondary and tertiary education, and as stepped its efforts to improve the quality of education to all learners. Cuba also congratulated Zambia for efforts to combat gender based violence, in particular the adoption of a national plan of action, as well as guidelines for the treatment of victims. It also expressed its gratitude to Zambia for the acceptance of its recommendation in relation to access to health services.

687. Gabon noted with satisfaction that many efforts have been made by Zambia to promote and protect human rights. It encouraged Zambia to hold-fast to the constitutional reforms undertaken, as well as those reforms undertaken in a range of areas that relate to human rights. In the final analysis, these reforms will contribute to strengthening the rule of law in a country that is fast becoming a model for democracy in the African continent.

688. Morocco welcomed the positive and constructive engagement of Zambia as well as the open-mindedness shown throughout the review, which bore witness to the firm commitment of Zambia to the promotion and protection of human rights, despite many difficulties and obstacles. Morocco welcomed the decision of Zambia to accept the majority of the recommendations. It also welcomed the affirmed commitment to strengthen national policies for the promotion and protection of human rights. Morocco reiterated its appreciation to Zambia for the efforts made to strengthen the capacities of good governance.

689. The Philippines noted Zambias significant human and financial constraints in fully implementing the law on trafficking in persons. The Philippines also noted Zambias acceptance its recommendation to continue to cooperate with development partners order to enhance the financial and technical capacity needed to implement this law. The Philippines welcomed Zambias acceptance of its recommendation to mainstream the rights of women and children through human rights education.

690. South Africa commended Zambia inter alia for its constructive engagement with the universal periodic review process and welcomed the additional information contained in the Addendum. It noted that during the review Zambia outlines key priority areas such as education, health care, agricultural development, and housing, and encouraged Zambia to continue to prioritise these areas, particularly during the implementation of accepted recommendations.

691. The Sudan paid tribute to Zambia for its commitment to the UPR process, in addition to the efforts made to strengthen human rights. It also congratulated Zambia for the dialogue in which it engaged. It stated that comments should not be imposed any State and should take into account the priorities and needs of the State concerned. The Sudan expressed appreciation for the clarification and responses provided by Zambia.

692. Thailand expressed appreciation for Zambias careful response to the recommendations and thanked Zambia for accepting both of its recommendations. It noted the efforts made and measures taken by Zambia to enhance the human rights situation in the country. Thailand stated that it stood ready to explore venues of cooperation and to exchange good practices.

693. Togo extended its congratulations to Zambia for efforts to protect the rights of persons with disabilities, to combat sexual violence and to increase the school enrolment rate. It thanked Zambia for accepting and taking into account its recommendations concerning the implementation of the right to health, the ratification of the Optional Protocol to CEDAW and the abolition of the death penalty. Togo called on the international community to assist Zambia with the implementation of the accepted recommendations.

694. Algeria stated that the additional provided by Zambia was yet another indication of the importance it attached to the UPR process. Algeria expressed appreciation for the acceptance of a large number of recommendations by Zambia, including those recommendations made by Algeria. It stated that the commitment by Zambia to promote and protect human rights was reflected inter alia by the strengthening of the institutional framework. The various legislative measures taken by Zambia could only contribute to the strengthening of law and democracy. Algeria stated that it was pleased that Zambia had prioritised the improvement of the quality of life of its population, which will contribute to the strengthening of economic, social and cultural rights.

695. Botswana commended Zambia for accepting the majority of the recommendations, which demonstrated its commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights. It further commended Zambia for the legislative reforms undertaken, which included the enactment and implementation of the Anti-Gender-Based Violence Act and the Anti-Corruption Act.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

696. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Zambia, five stakeholders made statements.

697. Associazione Comunita Papa Giovanni XXIII (APG23) noted that Zambia adopted the Persons with Disabilities Act 2012, and called on Zambia to ensure that all schools were accessible to children with disabilities, provide special education programmes and increase the number of teachers trained in special education. APG23 recommended the full eradication of corporal punishment, and any acts of violence against children at school. It urged Zambia to fully implement CEDAW, especially Article 10, and carry out awareness campaigns that encourage girls to attend school. APG23 stated that Zambia should take steps to guarantee the full realisation of the right to adequate food and expressed concern at the lack of skills and tools to prevent and treat malnutrition.

698. Save the Children International welcomed Zambias acceptance of several recommendations relating to childrens rights. The ratification of the OP-CRC-IC will provide opportunities for children to seek international redress in cases where national systems fail, and will also complement and reinforce the implementation of the Anti-Human Trafficking Act of 2008. Redefining the minimum age of criminal responsibility will result in younger children being protected from passing through the criminal justice system. Save the Children called on Zambia to harmonise the definition of the child in all legislation in line with the CRC; and for the implementation of Recommendation 103.54 which related to easy and effective free birth registration.

699. Edmund Rice International Limited, speaking also on behalf of Franciscans International, International Volunteerism Organization for Women, Education and Development and Istituto Internazionale Maria Ausiliatrice delle Salesiane di Don Bosco, stated that there was continued discrimination that lead to poor educational outcomes for vulnerable children. ERI expressed concern that alcohol abuse among underage drinkers was not addressed during the review. It welcomed the acknowledgement by Zambia of the impact of poverty on the increased number of street children and its efforts to guarantee a sustainable solution. It urged Zambia to follow the United Nations Guiding Principles on business and human rights.

700. RADDHO expressed support for the actions taken by Zambia in the area of education and childrens rights, as well as in combating sexual violence and promoting gender equality. It expressed appreciation for efforts made to combat corruption and stated that such efforts would be more effective if they could result in domestic legislation, in conformity with the United Nations Convention against Corruption. RADDHO hoped that consultations held within the ambit of the constitutional review will result in the abolition of the death penalty and that domestic legislation would be brought in line with the commitments of Zambia on issues such as elimination of all forms of discrimination against women. It raised concern in relation to the deteriorating conditions of detention; and the restrictions imposed on the press.

701. Bischfliches Hilfswerk Misereor e.V. welcomed the commitment of Zambia to enact the Access to Information Bill. It applauded the efforts to ensure broad based consultation and input in drafting the Bill and appreciated the invitation to civil society to sit on the government task force. Bischfliches Hilfswerk Misereor e.V. noted with concern the repeated postponements of the presentation of the Bill to parliament and called on Zambia not to postpone the presentation of the Bill to parliament any further.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

702. The delegation clarified that recommendations 103.1, 103.2, 103.4, 103.6, 103,9, 103.10, 103.12, 103.13, 103.14, 103.15, 103.16, 103.19, 103.20, 103.21, 103.22, 103.23, 103.24, 103.32, 103.33, 103.34, 103.35, 103.37, 103.38, 103.39, 103.40, 103.41, 103.42, 103.45, 103.46, 103.47, 103.48, 103.51, and 103.53 have been rejected.

703. In response to issues that have been raised, the delegation stated that the Supreme Court has decided more than five years ago that corporal punishment was unconstitutional, and constituted inhuman and degrading treatment. Corporal punishment was illegal and no longer sanctioned in schools. As regards the plea to reduce malnutrition, the delegation stated that Zambia was committed to all efforts to improving the living standards of its people, but that there were budgetary constraints.

704. The delegation reiterated that the freedom of information bill will be taken to Parliament this year. There has been increase in the freedom of the press and the Government is committed to further addressing this matter within the remit of the current constitutional making process.

705. The delegation thanked the speakers for their comments and assured the Council that Zambia will take them into account when implementing the accepted recommendations.

Japan

706. The review of Japan was held on 31 October 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Japan in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/JPN/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/JPN/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/JPN/3).

707. At its 37th meeting, on 14 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Japan (see section C below).

708. The outcome of the review of Japan comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/14), the views of Japan concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group (see also A/HRC/22/JPN/Add.1).

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

709. During the adoption of the outcome of the second review of Japan, the Deputy Permanent Representative of Japan to the United Nations at Geneva, referred to the essential role that the Council plays in the protection and promotion of human rights worldwide. It noted that in order to make the universal periodic review mechanism more effective it is crucial that each State voluntarily participates in the process. Japan considers that issues of human rights and fundamental freedoms in each country are legitimate issues of concern for the international community while the state has the basic responsibility to guarantee them. As such, Japan is engaged in efforts of the international community to promote and protect human rights in a spirit of dialogue and cooperation, with due consideration paid to various national and regional differences as well as historical and cultural backgrounds.

710. Japan participated in its second review in a forthcoming manner and thanked all States for their constructive and valuable comments. Civil society also played an important role in the review process. Japan received positive feedback on efforts to improve its domestic human rights situation and on its cooperation with United Nations human rights mechanisms, such as through the issuance of a standing invitation to Special Procedures, implementation of bilateral human rights consultations, and contribution to international cooperation.

711. The delegation indicated that the process of examining the recommendations required the involvement of many ministries, just as for the formulation of the national report. The careful examination of all recommendations provided an opportunity for a frank exchange with representatives of civil society.

712. Japan noted that it has clearly indicated in the Addendum document which recommendations enjoy its support. All other recommendations were noted by Japan.

713. Among the 174 recommendations received during its second review, Japan agreed to follow up, or partially follow up, 125. They include those to ratify all major international human rights treaties; to further promote protection of the rights of women, children, and persons with disabilities; to provide human rights training to civil servants; and to offer increased countermeasures to combat human trafficking. Japan is pleased to commit itself to follow up the majority of the recommendations it was given.

714. As explained in the Addendum, and following careful examination of recommendations, however, Japan is unable to accept other 26 recommendations. Regarding 23 remaining recommendations, Japan noted that is has already sufficient measures in place to address these situations. Japan provided an explanation of its position during the review and in the Addendum document.

715. Japan reported on progress in the implementation of accepted recommendations from its first review, as explained in the national report and during the second review. Japan also presented an independent midterm update on follow-up after its first review, and it intends to do the same with a view to their third review.

716. Japan intends to appropriately follow up on the recommendations from the second review to which Japan is committing itself. It further reported on some progress made since its second review. For example, and based on the standing invitation to Special Procedures issued in March 2011, the Special Rapporteur on the Right to Health visited Japan in November 2012. To increase awareness on the results of the review, Japan plans to post a translated version of the outcome report on Japans Ministry of Foreign Affairs website.

717. The delegation noted that the universal periodic review plays a crucial role in supporting every countrys efforts to improve its human rights situation. Japan is of the view that, in order to make the universal periodic review an even more effective mechanism, recommendations should be clear, concise, and realizable and their number should be reduced from the present level.

718. The delegation noted that Japan was again elected as a member of the Council for the period of 2013-2015. Japan issued a pledge document entitled Japans Contribution to the Promotion and Protection of International Human Rights which details its commitments in the area of human rights. Japan will continue, as a member of the Council, to actively contribute and work to further improve Japans human rights situation, as well as to strengthen respect for human rights at the international level.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

719. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Japan, 13 delegations made statements. The statements of the delegations that were unable to deliver them owing to time constraints[57] are posted on the extranet of the Human Rights Council, if available.

720. The Islamic Republic of Iran noted that two of the three recommendations it had made to Japan had been accepted. The Islamic Republic of Iran encouraged Japan to accelerate its efforts in particular with regard to the elimination of discrimination against children of ethnic minorities, non-Japanese nationality and children with disabilities.

721. The Lao Peoples Democratic Republic noted some positive achievements including, among others, in the area of disaster reduction policies and reconstruction, the rights of the child, combating human trafficking, the rights of persons with disabilities, prevention of violence against women and to advance womens rights. It further noted Japans achievements in the field of socio-economic development and the realization of the Millennium Development Goals.

722. Malaysia expressed its appreciation to Japan for its commitment and engagement with the universal periodic review. It applauded all efforts made by Japan in the field of human rights, as presented in its report during the review. Malaysia was pleased to note Japans readiness in accepting recommendations put forward by Member States, including those made by Malaysia, and it looked forward to the continued engagement of Japan with the universal periodic review mechanism.

723. Myanmar commended Japans constructive and active participation in the second cycle of the review. Myanmar was pleased to note that Japan had accepted a great number of recommendations made by member countries, including Myanmar. It wished Japan a great success in following up on these recommendations.

724. The Philippines appreciated the sincere apologies offered by Japan to all known comfort women who suffered immeasurable pain. It welcomed Japans parliamentary approval for the ratification of the Palermo Protocol on trafficking in persons and indicated that it awaits Japans further actions to overcome legal impediments to conclude its ratification. The Philippines was also optimistic that Japan will soon conclude its review of the legal implications of its possible ratification of the International Convention for the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Their Families.

725. The Republic of Korea appreciated Japans commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights, including efforts to strengthen the institutional framework for the advancement of womens rights including the adoption of the Third Basic Plan for Gender Equality. The Republic of Korea urged Japan to recognize its legal responsibility for the issue of the so-called comfort women and to take appropriate measures acceptable to the victims, as recommended by the international community.

726. The Republic of Moldova welcomed Japans efforts to improve its domestic human rights situations as well as to contribute to the protection and promotion of human rights at the international level. It applauded Japans engagement with the universal periodic review mechanism and for involving civil society. It acknowledged Japans commitment to address domestic and sexual violence against women and measures to fight against trafficking in persons.

727. Romania commended Japan for accepting to follow-up on the majority of the recommendations received during its review. Romania believed that implementation of the universal periodic review recommendations cannot but contribute to progress towards the compliance with the international human rights standards and saluted the commitments undertaken by Japan when running for elections for the Council.

728. Thailand commended Japans continued efforts to undertake a national plan and awareness raising campaigns through cooperation between the public and private sectors, as well as to implement relevant legislations with a view to eliminating violence against women and promoting gender equality. It further recognized Japans efforts to assist victims of sexual and other gender-based violence. Thailand also appreciated Japans support to their recommendations to further eliminate gender stereotypes against women.

729. Viet Nam commended Japans constructive approach to the universal periodic review, as well as for its seriousness in providing detailed feedback on received recommendations. It appreciated Japans acceptance of recommendations including Viet Nams recommendations on fostering holistic approaches on gender equality, in particular empowering womens social and economic rights and curbing domestic violence. It acknowledged Japans current challenges and great efforts in though moments.

730. Algeria noted with appreciation the acceptance by Japan of the majority of the recommendations, including Algerias recommendations to increase efforts to prevent sexual exploitation of children and to prosecute the authors of such acts, to ensure a greater political representation and participation of women in public life and to address the wage gap between men and women. It further reiterated its appreciation to the engagement of Japan in international cooperation and its contributions aimed at achieving the Millennium Development Goals by developing countries.

731. Botswana commended Japan for its achievements in the promotion and protection of human rights, including inter-alia, the promotion of disaster reduction policies; to uphold the rights of the child and to combat human trafficking, and initiatives to prevent violence against women. It noted that Japan had reaffirmed its pledges and commitments to continue to improve its domestic human rights situation as well as its commitments to contribute to the protection and protection of human rights at the international level.

732. China regretted that Japan had not accepted some important recommendations. It noted that Japan had not treated earnestly and appropriately the issue of the so-called comfort women. China urged Japan to accept and implement relevant recommendations, apologize for the issue and compensate the victims. China further indicated that Japan should face up its serious gender inequality, as well as its extensive problem of violence against women and children, and to take effective measures without delay to implement relevant recommendations from the universal periodic review.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

733. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Japan, nine other stakeholders made statements.

734. International Federation for Human Rights Leagues regretted that Japan had rejected recommendations related to the criminal justice system, in particular regarding a moratorium or abolition of the death penalty and a reform of substitute detention in police stations. It further noted that despite a very low homicide rate, there had been an increase in the number of death sentences and more sentences had been executed.

735. Amnesty International (AI) welcomed Japans acceptance of recommendations to establish a national human rights institution in accordance with the Paris Principles and called on Japan to give immediate effect to recommendations accepted. AI regretted Japans rejection of recommendations regarding the death penalty, including to introduce a moratorium on executions with a view to full abolition, as well as to abolish the substitute detention system or to bring it into line with international standards. It regretted Japans rejection of recommendations to accept responsibility for Japans military sexual slavery system. AI urged Japan to reconsider its position on these issues.

736. Save the Children International welcomed acceptance of the recommendations calling on Japan to consider the early ratification of the third Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child, as well as on measures to protect the right to health and life of residents living in Fukushima. It highlighted Japans decision to co-sponsor the Council and United Nations General Assembly resolutions on the Optional Protocol and hoped that Japan will sign and ratify the third Optional Protocol soon. It called on Japan to share their experiences of Fukushima with the international community, including during the 2015 Third United Nations World Conference on Disaster Risk Reduction.

737. The International Lesbian and Gay Association (ILGA) welcomed the responses of Japan to recommendations requesting to prohibit and eliminate discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity and to protect the rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people. It appreciated positive steps in recent years towards protecting the rights of LGBT people by changing relevant policies. It noted however that challenges remain towards achieving equality and well-being of LGBT people.

738. The Istituto Internazionale Maria Ausiliatrice delle Salesiane di Don Bosco welcomed the positive participation of Japan in its second review and urged it to accept recommendations concerning the rights of children. It called on Japan to reform the education system in order to promote students creativity, freedom and individual talents, to revise the national legal system in order to explicitly prohibit corporal punishment in all settings by law and, to adopt all measures to implement recommendation 147.155 to protect children and other residents living in Fukushima.

739. Reporters Without Borders International (RWB) reported on the lack of official information concerning the Fukushima disaster, as well as on media reports regarding lack of access to journalists and total lack of transparency. It further referred to media reports about an investigative journalist that had been brought to justice with a view to hinder the publication of his work, and indicated that the public is still waiting for an official report of the incident. RWB noted that not a single recommendation concerning freedom of expression had been made during the review. It hoped that Japan would recognize its obligation to respect the right of the public to access information.

740. While welcoming acceptance by Japan of a number of recommendations, the International Movement Against All Forms of Discrimination and Racism (IMADR) indicated it was also confused and concerned at the work accept to follow up, as it considered that many of the recommendations can be or need to be implemented immediately. IMADR was disappointed that many of the recommendations from the first cycle were not yet implemented. It regretted that no progress was made towards the establishment of a national human rights institution in accordance with the Paris Principles. Referring to article 14 of the Constitution, it also noted that discrimination of any kind must be explicitly prohibited, prevented and remedies for victims ensured through domestic legislation. It further regretted that Japan is rejecting the withdrawal of its reservation to ICERD article 4. IMADR requested Japan to take genuine and concrete actions to implement accepted recommendations in cooperation with the civil society.

741. Human Rights Now (HRN) called on Japan to implement the universal periodic review recommendations on the ratification of the optional protocols of human rights treaties, as well as the establishment of the national human rights institution in accordance with the Paris Principles, without further delay. It also urged Japan to fully implement recommendations regarding the rights to health of people affected by the nuclear accident in Fukushima in 2011. HRN called on Japan to respect and implement the recommendations of the forthcoming report of the United Nations Special Rapporteur on the Right to Health, who visited Japan last year.

742. The Japanese Association for the Right to Freedom of Speech referred to the issue of distribution of tracts critical to government as an exercise of censorship, as raised during the review of Japan. It noted that during its review, Japan responded that the problem is not the substance of the tract but the place where the tract was distributed. The decision is made fairly taking into account the feeling of the residents of that place, the evidences and the relevant laws. It stressed that all the cases of people arrested, indicted and tried were found guilty by the court so far concern the distribution of political tracts that are critical to the government.

4. Concluding remarks of the State under review

743. The delegation reiterated its appreciation to those who actively participated in Japans Universal Periodic Review. While noting that Japans position on all recommendations is outlined in the Addendum, the delegation provided further information on several points.

744. On the issue of comfort women raised, Japan feels grieved at the thought of those who have experienced immeasurable pain and suffering. It also considers that this should not develop into a political or a diplomatic issue. Japan has extended its maximum support to the Asian Womens Fund since its establishment in 1995 and will continue to do so to implement follow-up activities of the Fund.

745. The issue of reparations, property and claims concerning the Second World War has been legally settled with the countries that are parties to the San Francisco Peace Treaty and relevant bilateral treaties, agreements, and instruments.

746. As stated in the Addendum and as already explained during the session of the Working Group, the delegation noted that Japans view on the death penalty is that it is a matter that should be carefully examined and determined by each individual State based on public opinion, trends in crime, and criminal justice policy. The majority of Japanese people believe that, in cases of the most heinous crimes, the death penalty is unavoidable and that, given that such cases show no sign of decline, it would not be appropriate to abolish the death penalty.

747. It has been two years since the Great East Japan Earthquake in 2011. In close consultation with disaster-affected areas, Japan is committed to improve the situation of those affected and to restore the areas as soon as possible. Japan is willing to share its lessons learned and experiences with the world community, including on the occasion of 2015 United Nations World Conference on Disaster Risk Reduction to held in Japan.

748. Additionally, Japan is providing financial and technical support to Fukushima Prefecture for the mid-to-long-term health management of its citizens, especially children. Japan has received analysis and evaluations from international organizations such as the WHO, UNCEAR, and the ICRP and is providing appropriate health management of its residents based on scientific and ethical practice.

749. Japan has continuously worked to advance human rights and fundamental freedoms in the country and will spare no effort in making improvements.

Peru

750. The review of Peru was held on 1 November 2012 in conformity with all the relevant provisions contained in relevant Council resolutions and decisions, and was based on the following documents:

(a) The national report submitted by Peru in accordance with the annex to Council resolution 5/1, paragraph 15 (a) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/PER/1);

(b) The compilation prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (b) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/PER/2);

(c) The summary prepared by OHCHR in accordance with paragraph 15 (c) (A/HRC/WG.6/14/PER/3).

751. At its 38th meeting, on 15 March 2013, the Council considered and adopted the outcome of the review of Peru (see section C below).

752. The outcome of the review of Peru comprises the report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review (A/HRC/22/15), the views of Peru concerning the recommendations and/or conclusions, as well as its voluntary commitments and replies presented before the adoption of the outcome by the plenary to questions or issues that were not sufficiently addressed during the interactive dialogue in the Working Group (see also A/HRC/22/15/Add.1).

1. Views expressed by the State under review on the recommendations and/or conclusions as well as on its voluntary commitments and on the outcome

753. Peru recognized the importance of the UPR as a mechanism that promotes dialogue at the national and international levels as well as the sharing of best practices on human rights in the world. Peru had therefore fully cooperated with this mechanism based on the conviction that an honest exchange of ideas and experiences between States and other relevant actors is essential in guiding international cooperation towards full compliance with human rights obligations.

754. Peru stated that its experiences during the first and second UPR cycles allowed it to carry out an assessment of its public policies on human rights, verify progress made, identify remaining challenges and make decisions to ensure the full enjoyment of human rights for all, as was the creation of the Vice-Ministry on Human Rights and Access to Justice and the adoption of the Prior Consultation Act for indigenous peoples.

755. It added that the greatest example of Perus commitment to the UPR was the fact that it had immediately accepted 120 of the 129 recommendations made. Peru indicated that it had carefully analyzed the nine remaining pending recommendations and provided its response to these in writing, which can be found in document A/HRC/22/15/Add.1. It stated that it would listen to the interventions made by States and representatives of civil society during the adoption of the Working Group report that day in the same spirit of cooperation and would provide additional information if appropriate.

2. Views expressed by Member and observer States of the Council on the review outcome

756. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Peru, nine delegations made statements. The statements of the stakeholders that were unable to deliver them owing to time constraints[58] are posted on the extranet of the Human Rights Council, if available.

757. Romania commended Peru for the spirit of openness and transparency it had shown during the second UPR cycle, in particular its commitment to make further efforts with a view to improving the human rights situation. It noted that the large majority of the 129 recommendations received had been accepted and expressed the conviction that the implementation of the recommendations will mark concrete advances towards compliance with international human rights standards.

758. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela noted that Peru had fully cooperated with the UPR Working Group. It observed that the value given to the implementation of the recommendations accepted during the first cycle had been clear, and noted particularly Perus ratification of important international human rights instruments and the creation of new institutions aimed at protecting human rights. It noted further the reduction of poverty by more than a half in only seven years and the adoption of a national policy for the elderly. It recommended the adoption of the Working Group report.

759. Algeria greatly appreciated the acceptance by Peru of a large number of the recommendations received especially those made Algeria. It congratulated Peru for the different initiatives it had adopted for the promotion and protection of human rights, in particular the countrys commitment to the promotion of economic, social and cultural rights. Algeria highlighted the creation in 2011 of a Ministry for Development and Social Integration, of a Ministry of Culture in 2010, and a Ministry of the Environment in 2008. It recommended that the final UPR WG report be adopted.

760. Cuba recognized efforts made by Peru for the protection of vulnerable groups, noting the adoption of the plan for equal opportunities for persons with disabilities 2009-2018 and the national policy for the elderly. Cuba was encouraged by efforts made on gender, noting important initiatives to combat domestic violence and discrimination as well as State intervention at different levels through the national plan to combat violence against women 2009-2015. It also highlighted efforts to increase literacy. Cuba was grateful for the acceptance of recommendations to continue implementing policies and programmes for the reduction of poverty especially extreme poverty and to continue developing measures to permit universal access to education.

761. Ecuador recognized progress made by Peru in human rights, highlighting the high number of recommendations accepted in the second cycle. It noted the ratification of the International Convention for the Protection of All Person from Forced Disappearance and the adoption of the law on prior consultation of indigenous peoples. It noted, additionally, measures to promote the rights of persons with disabilities; measures to strengthen the protection of the elderly and prohibition of discrimination; the important measures to guarantee the rights of women including measures to protect against violence; and the priority given to the eradication of poverty.

762. Malaysia thanked Peru for its transparent and constructive engagement with the UPR. It was pleased with the responses provided during the review. Malaysia noted with appreciation that Peru had accepted the recommendations it had proposed. It expressed awareness of the need to afford all countries as well as Peru the necessary time in which to continue making improvements in the promotion and protection of human rights on the ground. It wished the delegation well as it continues to implement the UPR recommendations and urged the adoption of the report.

763. Morocco highlighted measures adopted since its review in November, particularly: the adoption of law on disabled person in December 2012; and the creation in February 2013 of a multi-sectoral commission for the implementation of the right to prior consultation as a follow up to the law on prior consultation of indigenous persons. Morocco was pleased that the second cycle had permitted Peru to follow up on progress made and remaining challenges and implement recommendations. It expressed satisfaction at the acceptance of 120 of the 129 recommendations, including those made by Morocco and thanked Peru for the information provided on the nine remaining recommendations.

764. The Philippines appreciated Perus acceptance of 120 out of 129 recommendations received at the time it presented its report to the UPR Working Group. It acknowledged Perus promotion of dialogue with stakeholders in the preparation of its reply to the remaining recommendations. The Philippines welcomed Perus readiness to act to improve the standard of protection of migrants and their families and appreciated the acceptance of its recommendations to ratify International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of Migrant Workers and Members of Their Families and its openness to pursue ratification of ILO Convention 189 on Decent Work for Domestic Workers.

765. The Republic of Moldova thanked Peru for the complementary information provided on the recommendations received during the 14th Working Group session. It welcomed the inclusive approach of Peru in the preparation of its national report and applauded the Governments policies aimed at consolidating democracy and the rule of law. It also welcomed legal and institutional developments to protect human rights and efforts to combat discrimination against women, to include a gender perspective in its public policies and combat violence against children and all other forms of humiliating treatment of adolescents.

3. General comments made by other relevant stakeholders

766. During the adoption of the outcome of the review of Peru, eight other stakeholders made statements.

767. Amnesty International was concerned that the failure to consult with local communities on development projects has on occasion resulted in mass protests with reports of excessive use of force by police. It was concerned that Legislative Decrees N 1094 and 1095 allow the military to be deployed to deal with hostile groups a term that could be interpreted to include human rights defenders. It also noted the lack of legal instruments to regulate the provision in the Penal Code providing therapeutic abortion and called on Peru to create a national protocol to address this. It urged Peru to ensure that the National Ombudsman has the necessary resources to carry out its function as the national preventive mechanism under OP-CAT.

768. Save the Children International, speaking also on behalf of SOS Childrens Villages International, expressed concern that the review of the Children and Adolescents Code does not include the principles of the Convention on the Rights of the Child nor take into account the General Comments of the Committee on the Rights of the Child. They called on Peru to: immediately approve a new Code that follows these principles; modify the regulations that prevent adolescents from having access to free sexual and reproductive health services and review laws on sexual crimes against children. They also urged: prioritization of the protection of the most vulnerable children; and the immediate recovery of children held by terrorist groups in compliance of OP-CRC-AC.

769. Franciscans International, speaking also on behalf of Sisters of Mercy of the Americas and VIVAT International, noted that Peru had accepted recommendations calling for targeted measures for racial minorities and urged the Government to publish statistics disaggregated by race as a necessary condition for their implementation. Noting the acceptance of recommendations to promote economic, cultural and social rights, they recalled that abuses related mining activities had a prominent role in Perus UPR and that a human rights based approach should be at the forefront of economic development policies. They also urged Peru to refrain from using emergency declarations and arbitrary application of criminal law to inhibit human rights activities.

770. Action Canada for Population and Development congratulated Peru for accepting the recommendation to consider being guided by the Yogyakarta Principles in the preparation of its policies. This commitment should include the adoption of a law permitting the legal recognition in personal documentation of the name and sex that persons identify themselves with. It noted that in 2009 Peru approved the law on the disciplinary regulations of the national police which punishes homosexual relations within that institution and urged that these norms be reviewed. It also noted reports of frequent violence and murder of LGBT persons in Peru, which often go unpunished for lack of investigation and expressed satisfaction with the acceptance of the recommendation to consider adopting a law on crimes based on sexual orientation, though sexual identity should be added.

771. International Gay and Lesbian Association thanked Peru for accepting recommendations aimed at eliminating discrimination against LGBT persons. It noted that though the Constitution prohibits discrimination of any kind, in reality discriminatory practices are systemic. It added that the adoption of the law against discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity has been blocked by fundamentalist sectors and hoped that the law for gender identity does not suffer the same fate. Moreover the National Human Rights Action Plan (2012-2016) did not take into account the substantive contributions of the LGBT community. It urged the Government to explicitly apply the Yogyakarta Principles as guide in its elaboration of public policies.

772. Center for Reproductive Rights, Inc. commended Peru for accepting recommendations on reproductive rights (116.96 and 116.97). It noted the lack of implementation of Human Rights Committees views K.L v Peru and L.C v Peru issued by CEDAW, cases where women were denied access to legal therapeutic abortion. It remained concerned regarding the adoption of the national protocol to therapeutic abortion as the Gender Equality Plan 2012-2017 specifies that this should take place by 2017, which is after the next UPR review. It was also concerned at the fact that Peru neither accepted nor rejected the recommendation to review its restrictive interpretation of therapeutic adoption and decriminalize abortion in cases of rape as recommended by CEDAW.
